contextId.occurrenceNote: The creatures were flying in the air after they left the ground. Alternate translation: “So when the creatures left the ground and went up into the air” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: When the living creatures rose up from the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to make explicit that Ezekiel is to carve a picture. Alternate translation: “carve a picture of the city of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: carve the city of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to make explicit why they will ration the bread. “they will carefully divide their bread because they fear that there will not be enough” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they will eat bread while rationing it in anxiety

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “everyone will look at his brother and worry about how much food his brother eats and waste away” or (2) “every one of them will be dismayed and waste away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: every man will be dismayed at his brother and waste away

contextId.occurrenceNote: “with all of those things of yours that I hate.” You may need to make explicit that this refers to idols: “with all your idols, which I hate” or “with all your disgusting idols.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: with all your hateful things

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to make explicit why Yahweh will be satisfied. Alternate translation: “I will be satisfied that I have punished them enough” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will be satisfied

contextId.occurrenceNote: When Yahweh says that people will know that he is Yahweh, he is implying that they will know that he is the one true God who has supreme authority and power. Alternate translation: “understand that I am Yahweh, the one true God” or “realize that I, Yahweh, have supreme power and authority” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: know that I am Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Behold! The day is coming!” You may need to make explicit which day is coming. Alternate translation: “Behold! The day when I will punish you is coming!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Behold, the day! Behold, it is coming!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Shaving the head was a sign of sadness. Alternate translation: “all of them will shave their heads” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: baldness on all of their heads

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the inner northern gate of the temple.” The temple was surrounded by two walls, one inside the other. This gate was on the north side of the inner wall. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the inner northern gate

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to make explicit which courtyard. “the temple courtyard” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the courtyard

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to make explicit which wall. Alternate translation: “the wall all around the temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the wall all around

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to make explicit what the people are to begin to do at the sanctuary. Alternate translation: “Begin to kill the ones who do not have the mark at my sanctuary” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Begin at my sanctuary

contextId.occurrenceNote: As one faces east, “the right side” is toward the south. Alternate translation: “on the south side” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: on the right side

contextId.occurrenceNote: Since the people had seen what Ezekiel was doing, their question implies their desire to know the reason why he was doing it. Alternate translation: “What is the meaning of the things you are doing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: What are you doing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “in whose midst” refers to Jerusalem, while “they” refers to the “house of Israel.” Alternate translation: “who are in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in whose midst they are

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of enabling the Chaldeans to bring the prince to Babylon as if he himself were bringing the prince there. Alternate translation: “I will cause the Chaldeans to bring him to Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will bring him to Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that the visions that the prophets receive and communicate to the people fail to happen. Alternate translation: “every prophetic vision fails to happen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: every vision fails

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to the days in which Israel will be judged. Alternate translation: “The days of judgment are coming soon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: The days have drawn near

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “matter” refers to the things that Yahweh says will happen. Alternate translation: “What I say will no longer be delayed” or “What I say will happen soon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: The matter will no longer be delayed

contextId.occurrenceNote: You can supply the implicit information here. Alternate translation: “resist the enemy armies” or “defend the city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: resist in battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the time when Yahweh will judge his people by means of an enemy army. Alternate translation: “the day of Yahweh’s judgment” or “the day when Yahweh judges you by sending enemy armies to attack you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the day of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that they make veils to put on the heads of people of different height. Alternate translation: “make veils for the heads of women of every stature” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: make veils for their heads of every size

contextId.occurrenceNote: The elders sat before Ezekiel in order to inquire of the Lord through Ezekiel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Some of the elders of Israel came to me and sat before me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to the many idols that the people worship. It is implied that the severity of Yahweh’s answer will as great as the number of idols that they worship. Alternate translation: “I, Yahweh, will give him the answer that he deserves because he worships so many idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I, Yahweh, will answer him according to the number of his idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh speaks of something that the people of Israel had actually done. They sacrificed their children to pagan idols. In these ancient pagan sacrifices, the people believed that the gods would eat the food that they offered to them. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “you sacrificed them to the images so that those images could devour them as food” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: you sacrificed them to the images to be devoured as food

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh speaks of something that the people of Israel had actually done. They sacrificed their children to pagan idols. It is implicit that she put them into the fire in order to offer them as burnt offerings to her images. Alternate translation: “sacrificed them as burnt offerings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: made them pass through the fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: Stripping a person naked in front of others was an action intended to humiliate the person. The word “nakedness” can be translated as an adjective. Alternate translation: “so they can see you completely naked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: so they see all your nakedness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Samaria and Sodom were both cities that Yahweh had judged for their idolatry and wickedness. Yahweh speaks of these cities being Jerusalem’s sisters to express that she belonged to a family that practiced idolatry and wickedness. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Your older sister was Samaria & your younger sister was the one living south of you, that is, Sodom

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jerusalem broke her marriage covenant with Yahweh, thereby showing that she did not care about the oaths that she had made to him. Alternate translation: “despised your oath to me by breaking the covenant that you made with me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: despised your oath by breaking the covenant

contextId.occurrenceNote: Willow trees grow in places where there is a lot of water. If the eagle planted the seed like a willow, it means that he planted it in a place with a lot of water. Alternate translation: “and planted the seed like one would plant a willow tree by water” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: planted it & like a willow

contextId.occurrenceNote: People often worshiped and offered sacrifices to pagan gods on the mountains. It is implied that this person has not participated in these kinds of pagan rituals. Alternate translation: “he does not eat meat sacrificed to idols on the mountains” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: he does not eat upon the mountains

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implicit that he has not approached a woman in order to sleep with her. Alternate translation: “approached a woman to sleep with her during her monthly period” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: approached a woman during her monthly period

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “firstborn of the womb” refers to the firstborn child of a woman. The phrase “made a sacrifice” can be translated with the verb “sacrifice.” Alternate translation: “they sacrificed every woman’s firstborn child” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they made a sacrifice of every firstborn of the womb

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a sign posted where the road divides into two roads. Alternate translation: “a sign will be posted where the road divides into two roads” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: a signpost will mark one of them as leading to a city

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the time when Yahweh will destroy them. Alternate translation: “so that the time of her destruction may come” or “so that the time may come for her to be destroyed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: so that her time may come

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the mountains” refer to the altars on the mountains that are dedicated to idols. They men eat meat that has been sacrificed to the idols in order to be have the blessing of false gods. Alternate translation: “they eat the meat that has been sacrificed to idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they eat on the mountains

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are all ways to express that the men have had slept with women they should not have and how sinful their actions are. Alternate translation: “They have raped unclean women during their menstrual period” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they have violated unclean women during their menstrual period

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are all ways to express that the men have had slept with women they should not have and how sinful their actions are. Alternate translation: “commit abominations by sleeping with their neighbors’ wives … make their own daughters-in-law shamefully unclean by sleeping with them … rape their own sisters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: commit abominations with their neighbors’ wives & make their own daughters-in-law shamefully unclean & abuse their own sisters

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that they have oppressed their neighbors by charging them too much interest. Alternate translation: “you have oppressed your neighbors and made them poor” or “you have made your neighbors poor by charging too much interest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: you have damaged your neighbors through oppression

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “her” refers to Israel. They “make many widows” by killing married men. Alternate translation: “they make many women into widows by killing their husbands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they make many widows within her

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he married them and they became his wives. Alternate translation: “they became my wives” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they became mine

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to when she was his wife. Alternate translation: “while she was still my wife” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: when she was mine

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies that she slept with all of these men and worshiped the idols they worshiped. Alternate translation: “she made herself unclean by sleeping with everyone she lusted for and by worshiping all their idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: she made herself unclean with everyone she lusted for—and with all their idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to how they had both made themselves unclean. Alternate translation: “Both sisters became unclean through their acts of prostitution” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: It was the same for both sisters

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to her bed where she slept with men and acted lustfully. Alternate translation: “her bed where she acted lustfully” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: her bed of lust

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that they slept with the woman. Alternate translation: “they slept with her and made her unclean” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they made her unclean with their promiscuousness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes the punishment in Babylon for married women who slept with men that are not their husbands. Alternate translation: “They will punish you as an adulteress, by cutting of your noses and your ears” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: They will cut off your noses and your ears

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to her prostitution as beginning in Egypt. Alternate translation: “which you began in the land of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: from the land of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have the same meaning. It means that they will be captured by the men they used to prostitute themselves to. Alternate translation: “allow you to be captured by those you hate and had turned away from” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: give you into the hand of the ones you hate & into the hand of the ones from whom you had turned away

contextId.occurrenceNote: She became unclean by worshiping the idols. Alternate translation: “became unclean by worshiping their idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: became unclean with their idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: “accept responsibility for the guilt of your sins with your idols.” This implies that they will be punished for their sins. Alternate translation: “receive the punishment for sinning by worshiping your idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: bear the guilt of your sins with your idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: Some cultures add bones to a fire because they burn longer than wood. This refers to the bones that remained after the best bones were placed in the pot. Alternate translation: “place the rest of the bones under the pot to fuel the fire” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: pile up the bones under it

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that the blood from those who were murdered in Jerusalem is still there. Alternate translation: “For the blood of those who were murdered among her is still there” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: For her blood is in the midst of her

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh is speaking about himself taking revenge on those who murdered the people in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “in order that I could see it and then be angry and get revenge” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: so it brings fury up to exact vengeance

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that the pile of wood is under the cooking pot that represents Jerusalem. “I will make the pile of wood on the fire under you even bigger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will also enlarge the pile of wood

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies that God will not forgive the sins of these people. Alternate translation: “and I will not forgive your sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in your iniquities

contextId.occurrenceNote: It may be helpful to specify the source of the fruit and milk. Alternate translation: “They will eat the fruit from your trees and drink the milk from your cattle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: They will eat your fruit and they will drink your milk

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “she” refers to the word “gates” which have “turned” on their hinges to open to Tyre. This phrase means that Tyre has now replaced Jerusalem as the city through which the traders from many nations pass. Alternate translation: “The gateway has opened to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: She has turned to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “king of kings” was a title, meaning that he was the greatest of kings, the king that other kings obeyed. Alternate translation: “Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, the greatest king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, king of kings

contextId.occurrenceNote: How Egypt would be a reminder can be stated clearly. The abstract nouns “reminder” and “iniquity” can be expressed with the verbs “remember” and “sin.” Alternate translation: “when Israel sees what I do to Egypt, Israel will remember how Israel sinned” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: they will be a reminder of the iniquity that Israel committed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The kind of hard work they did can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “to work hard at attacking Tyre” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: to do hard work against Tyre

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that on that day, Yahweh will punish people. Alternate translation: “It will soon be the day when Yahweh will punish you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: The day is near for Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh was comparing how many branches the trees had. Alternate translation: “None of the cypress trees had as many branches as the cedar” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: None among the cypress trees matched its branches

contextId.occurrenceNote: It was implied Yahweh was comparing the long branches of the cedar tree with the long branches of the plane tree. Alternate translation: “the plane tree did not have branches like the cedar tree” or “no plane tree had branches as long as the branches of the cedar tree” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the plane tree could not equal its boughs

contextId.occurrenceNote: The worms help the dead body to rot. Alternate translation: “your rotting body” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: your worm-filled corpse

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) This happened in the twelfth year after the Babylonians took the Israelites to Babylon or (2) this happened in the twelfth year after the Babylonians took Jehoiachin to Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in the twelfth year

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a question and command that the prophet is to ask the Egyptians. Alternate translation: “Go down and lie down with the uncircumcised. Ask them all: ‘Are you really more beautiful than anyone else?’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Are you really more beautiful than anyone else? Go down and lie down with the uncircumcised.

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that they must go down to Sheol. Alternate translation: “Go down to Sheol” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Go down

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Israelites did not respect people who were not circumcised. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: All of them are uncircumcised

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be made explicit who Pharaoh will see. Alternate translation: “Pharaoh will see all the dead people from other nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Pharaoh will look

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that Pharaoh will be comforted because the armies of other great kings also died. Alternate translation: “will comfort himself that he was not the only king whose entire army died” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: be comforted about all his multitudes

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that they eat blood by eating meat that still has blood in it. Yahweh had commanded them to drain out the blood. Alternate translation: “You eat meat with blood in it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: You eat blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that they defile their neighbor’s wives by sleeping with them. Alternate translation: “each man sleeps with his neighbor’s wife” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: each man defiles his neighbor’s wife

contextId.occurrenceNote: The fatty portions come from the sheep and the goats. Alternate translation: “You eat the fatty parts of the sheep and goats” or “You eat the best parts of the sheep and goats” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: You eat the fatty portions

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that the animals in the flock scattered because they did not have a shepherd to care for them or protect them. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “they scattered because they did not have a shepherd to care for them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they were scattered

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Mount Zion. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: my hill

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that Yahweh was protecting Israel and Judah. Alternate translation: “but Yahweh was there protecting Israel and Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: even when Yahweh was present with them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is speaking to the mountains. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “So, mountains of Israel, I will multiply upon you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: So I will multiply upon you

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that in the past children died because there was not enough food in the land. Now the land would produce enough food. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: you will no longer cause their children to die

contextId.occurrenceNote: It was implied that Yahweh would establish them in the land of Israel. Alternate translation: “I will set them in the land of Israel” or “I will cause them to live securely in the land of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will establish them

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that Magog is the land over which Gog rules. Alternate translation: “Gog who rules over the land of Magog” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Gog, the land of Magog

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression occurs twice in these verses. Some modern versions, however, interpret the Hebrew expression as “the chief of Rosh, Meshech, and Tubal.” This is another title for Gog. Alternate translation: “who is the chief prince of Meshech and Tubal” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the chief prince of Meshech and Tubal

contextId.occurrenceNote: In Jewish law, a dead body defiled anything it touched and made it “unclean.” Burying these bodies is spoken of as cleansing or purifying the land. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: will bury them in order to purify the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: In Jewish law, a dead body defiled anything it touched and made it “unclean.” Burying these bodies is spoken of as cleansing or purifying the land. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to cleanse the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: In Jewish law, a dead body defiled anything it touched and made it “unclean.” Burying these bodies is spoken of as cleansing or purifying the land. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: purify the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “our” refers to Ezekiel and the Israelites who have been in Babylon since the Babylonians forced King Jehoiachin to leave Jerusalem, but not to the reader. Alternate translation: “after we became captives” or “after the Babylonians took us as captives to Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])
contextId.quoteString: of our captivity

contextId.occurrenceNote: These were apparently different tables than the eight tables on which the sacrifices were killed. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “There were also four tables of cut stone” or “There were four other tables made of cut stone” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: There were four tables of cut stone

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that Ezekiel is comparing the prince’s land with the size of the land given to each of the tribes. Alternate translation: “The length will be the same as the length of one of the portions given to the tribes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: The length will correspond to the length of one of those portions

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that this is the amount of wheat that the people harvest. Alternate translation: “for every homer of wheat from the harvest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: for every homer of wheat

contextId.occurrenceNote: Each “long cubit” was about 54 centimeters. You may choose not to include this information if you give modern measurements instead of “cubits” as the UST does. Alternate translation: “These were the long cubits, which were the length of a regular cubit plus a handbreadth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: Each long cubit was a cubit and a handbreadth in length

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the width of a hand.” This was about 8 centimeters. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: a handbreadth

contextId.occurrenceNote: about 2.7 meters (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: five cubits

contextId.occurrenceNote: about one meter (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: two cubits

contextId.occurrenceNote: about 5.4 meters (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: A span was 23 centimeters. You may choose not to include this information if you give modern measurements instead of “cubits” as the UST does. Alternate translation: “about 23 centimeters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: one span

contextId.occurrenceNote: Each cubit was about 54 centimeters. Alternate translation: “500 cubits … 50 cubits wide” or “about 270 meters … about 27 meters wide” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: five hundred cubits & fifty cubits in width

contextId.occurrenceNote: Each long cubit was about 54 centimeters. Alternate translation: “1,000 cubits” or “about 540 meters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: one thousand cubits

contextId.occurrenceNote: “1/6 hin” or “a sixth part of a hin” or “about one-half liter” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bvolume]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-fraction]])
contextId.quoteString: a sixth of a hin

contextId.occurrenceNote: A hin is 3.7 liters. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bvolume]])
contextId.quoteString: a hin

contextId.occurrenceNote: about 220 liters (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bvolume]])
contextId.quoteString: homer

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may convert this to a modern measure. Alternate translation: “twenty-two liters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bvolume]])
contextId.quoteString: an ephah

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may convert this to a modern measure. Alternate translation: “four liters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bvolume]])
contextId.quoteString: a hin

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may convert this to a modern measure. Alternate translation: “each twenty-two liters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bvolume]])
contextId.quoteString: each ephah

contextId.occurrenceNote: about 11 grams (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bweight]])
contextId.quoteString: shekel

contextId.occurrenceNote: about 0.55 grams (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bweight]])
contextId.quoteString: gerahs

contextId.occurrenceNote: about 660 grams (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bweight]])
contextId.quoteString: mina

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the fifth day of the fourth month.” This is the fourth month of the Hebrew calendar. The fifth day is around the end of June on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the fourth month, and the fifth day of the month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the sixth month of the Hebrew calendar. The fifth day is near the beginning of September on Western calendars. Alternate translation: “the fifth day of the sixth month” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the sixth month, in the fifth day of the month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the fifth month of the Hebrew calendar. The tenth day is near the beginning of August on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the tenth day of the fifth month

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the tenth day of the tenth month” or “the 10th day of the 10th month.” This is the tenth month of the Hebrew calendar. The tenth day is near the beginning of January on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the tenth month, and on the tenth day of the month

contextId.occurrenceNote: “on the twelfth day of the tenth month.” This is the tenth month of the Hebrew calendar. The twelfth day is near the beginning of January on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the tenth month on the twelfth day of the month

contextId.occurrenceNote: “on the first day of the first month.” This is the first month of the Hebrew calendar. The first day is near the beginning of April. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: on the first of the first month

contextId.occurrenceNote: “in the seventh day of the first month.” This is the first month of the Hebrew calendar. The seventh day is near the beginning of April on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the first month, in the seventh day of the month

contextId.occurrenceNote: “on the first day of the third month.” This is the third month of the Hebrew calendar. This first day is near the beginning of June on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the third month, on the first day of the month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the twelfth and final month of the Hebrew calendar. The first day is near the end of February. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the twelfth month & on the first of the month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the tenth month of the Hebrew calendar. The fifth day is near the beginning of January on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: on the fifth day of the tenth month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the first month of the Hebrew calendar. The tenth day is in April on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the beginning of the year on the tenth day of the month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the first month of the Hebrew calendar. The first day is near the end of March on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: In the first month, on the first day of the month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the first month of the Hebrew calendar. The fourteenth day is near the beginning of April. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: In the first month on the fourteenth day of the month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the seventh month of the Hebrew calendar. The fifteenth day is near the beginning of October. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: In the seventh month on the fifteenth day of the month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a man’s name. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Buzi

contextId.occurrenceNote: A town in Babylon, about 80 kilometers southeast of the main city, which was also called Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Tel Aviv

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Diblah

contextId.occurrenceNote: men’s names (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Jaazaniah & Shaphan

contextId.occurrenceNote: grieving because the false god Tammuz had died (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: mourning for Tammuz

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Jaazaniah son of Azzur and Pelatiah son of Benaiah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a woman that means “her tent.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Oholah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a woman that means “my tent is in her.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Oholibah

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names places in Babylonia. These places represent the soldiers from these places. Alternate translation: “those from Pekod, Shoa, and Koa” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Pekod, Shoa, and Koa

contextId.occurrenceNote: “I will make all of Edom … from Teman to Dedan.” These are two cities at opposite ends of Edom. This means that Yahweh will destroy all of Edom. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make them & from Teman to Dedan

contextId.occurrenceNote: people who lived in the city of Kereth in Philistia (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Kerethites

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a small island off the coast of Syria. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Arvad

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city on the Syrian coast. Other versions call it by the name “Gebal.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-textvariants]])
contextId.quoteString: Byblos

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of places. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Persia, Lydia & Libya

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of places. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Arvad & Helek & Gammad

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a coastal region also known as Ionia. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Javan

contextId.occurrenceNote: the name of a place (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Beth Togarmah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a place. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Rhodes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a place. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Minnith

contextId.occurrenceNote: names of places (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Helbon & Zahar

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of places. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Dan & Javan & Izal

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of places. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Arabia & Kedar

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of places. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Sheba & Raamah

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of places. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Haran & Kanneh & Eden & Sheba & Ashur & Kilmad

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a place in the far northern part of Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Migdol

contextId.occurrenceNote: This the name of a town in southern Egypt. It is now called Aswan. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Syene

contextId.occurrenceNote: These borders of Cush were south of Syene. Some versions say Sudan or Ethiopia, the modern names of countries south of Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: the borders of Cush

contextId.occurrenceNote: the southern part of Egypt between the Delta and the land of Cush. This is also called Upper Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: the region of Pathros

contextId.occurrenceNote: Libya is a country west of Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Libya

contextId.occurrenceNote: Memphis was a very important city in Egypt. It was near modern-day Cairo. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Memphis

contextId.occurrenceNote: Pelusium is the name of a fortress in northern Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Pelusium

contextId.occurrenceNote: These were cities in northern Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Heliopolis and Bubastis

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a leader or king who ruled in the land of Magog. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Gog

contextId.occurrenceNote: This name means “Great Army.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Hamonah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a very large spring on the western side of the Salt Sea. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: En Gedi

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a large spring on the eastern side of the Salt Sea. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: En Eglaim

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of towns. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Hethlon & Zedad

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of towns. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Berothah & Sibraim & Hazer Hattikon & Hauran

contextId.occurrenceNote: the name of a town (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Hazar Enan

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a town. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Hauran

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of towns. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Tamar & Meribah Kadesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a town. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Hamath

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a command to stare at the model of the city as a symbol of punishing the city. Alternate translation: “stare at the city” or “stare at the city so that it will be harmed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: set your face against it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The mountains of Israel were far away, so Ezekiel could not see them, but staring in that direction would be a symbol of harming it. Alternate translation: “turn toward the mountains of Israel and stare” or “stare toward the mountains of Israel so that the people there will be harmed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: set your face against the mountains of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of being opposed to a person as if he were to set his face against that person. Alternate translation: “I will be against that man” or “I will oppose that man” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: I will set my face against that man

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of being opposed to them as if he were to set his face against them. Alternate translation: “I will be against them” or “I will oppose them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: I will set my face against them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to taking hold of another person’s hand as a sign of friendship and agreement. Here it represents the covenant oath that he made with the king of Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: reached out with his hand to make a promise

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “lift up his eyes” refers to looking toward something. With reference to idols, this gesture represents worshiping or praying to idols. Alternate translation: “worship the idols” or “pray to the idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: lift up his eyes to the idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “raised my hand” is a symbolic action that shows he will truly do what he has sworn to do. Alternate translation: “I … solemnly swore an oath” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: I & raised my hand to swear an oath

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “lifted up my hand” is a symbolic action that shows he will truly do what he has sworn to do. Alternate translation: “I myself also solemnly swore” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: I myself also lifted up my hand to swear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “lifted up my hand” is a symbolic action that shows he will truly do what he has sworn to do. Alternate translation: “I have solemnly sworn” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: I have lifted up my hand to swear

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a command to stare at Jerusalem as a symbol of punishing the people there. Alternate translation: “stare at Jerusalem” or “stare at Jerusalem so that the people there will be harmed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: set your face toward Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: In Ezekiel’s culture, slapping one’s thigh was a sign of grief. Some other translation use the gesture of beating one’s breast which is a sign of grief in many cultures. Alternate translation: “beat your chests” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: slap your thigh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means for him to clap his hands as a sign of his grief. Alternate translation: “clap your hands to show that you are very sad” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: hit your two hands together

contextId.occurrenceNote: “clap my hands.” Here clapping hands is a sign of triumph. Alternate translation: “clap my hands in triumph” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: hit my two hands together

contextId.occurrenceNote: “I have shaken my fist against” or “I have clapped my hands against.” This is a symbolic action that shows anger and disapproval. Alternate translation: “I have shown my anger and disapproval against” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: With my hand I have struck

contextId.occurrenceNote: In Israel, men would shave their beards to express sorrow, then cover their faces until their facial hair grew back. Yahweh told Ezekiel not to cover his facial hair in order to show that he had not shaved his face to express his sorrow. Alternate translation: “do not mourn by veiling your facial hair” or “do not mourn by shaving and covering your beard” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: do not veil your facial hair

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a command to stare at the people of Ammon as a symbol of punishing them. Alternate translation: “stare at the people of Ammon” or “stare at the people of Ammon so that they will be harmed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: set your face against the people of Ammon

contextId.occurrenceNote: These actions are ways to show strong emotions. In this case the people are cheering and showing their contempt against Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: You have clapped your hands and stamped your feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are expressions of grieving and mourning. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: they will cast dust up on their heads & hey will roll about in ashes

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are expressions of grieving and mourning. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: They will shave their heads bald for you and bind themselves with sackcloth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hissing was making a whistling sound through the teeth. It may have been out of dismay, grief, or surprise. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: hiss at you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “lift up my hand” is a symbolic action that shows he will truly do what he has sworn to do. Alternate translation: “I solemnly swear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: I myself will lift up my hand to swear

contextId.occurrenceNote: In those days a person would raise his right hand to show that he realized that God would punish him if he did not do what he swore to do. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: I lifted up my hand and swore

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are like beans, but their seeds are very small, round, and somewhat flat. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: lentils

contextId.occurrenceNote: a strong, smooth cloth made from a plant. It is worn by many people in places that are hot. Alternate translation: “smooth cloth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: linen

contextId.occurrenceNote: A dark gold-colored metal. It is made from mostly copper with tin added for strength. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: bronze

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Beryl” here is a very hard, valuable stone. This beryl was probably green or blue. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: beryl stone

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a type of spice that comes from the bark of a tree. “Cassia” is another name for this spice. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: cinnamon

contextId.occurrenceNote: a type of grass that people used as perfume and for medicine (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: calamus

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are all precious stones of different colors. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: ruby, topaz, emerald, chrysolite, onyx, jasper, sapphire, turquoise, and beryl

contextId.occurrenceNote: A plane tree was a large, leafy tree with strong branches. It is similar to a sycamore tree. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: plane tree

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ezekiel was to do this symbolic action to get the people’s attention. This was not applause. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: Clap your hands and stomp your foot

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the huge creature that lives in the water.” Yahweh calls Pharaoh a monster that lives in the water. The monster is probably a crocodile. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: the great sea monster

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “Alas” is an exclamation that expresses fear and sadness. Alternate translation: “Oh no, Lord Yahweh” or “Ah, Lord Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclamations]])
contextId.quoteString: Alas, Lord Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “Aha” is a sound people make when they discover something. Alternate translation: “Yes!” or “This is great!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclamations]])
contextId.quoteString: Aha!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This exclamation expresses the fear that people would feel about a certain day when terrible and frightening things will happen. Alternate translation: “Oh that day” or “Oh, what a frightening day is coming” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclamations]])
contextId.quoteString: Woe is the coming day

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

God speaks of making Pharaoh’s army weak as if he were to break Pharaoh’s arm, and of the army not being able to become strong again as if Pharaoh’s arm could not be healed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parables]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “arm” represents the powerful army of a king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parables]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have broken the arm of Pharaoh

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

These are God’s words to Pharaoh about Assyria. God gives his message in the form of a parable about a great cedar tree. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parables]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: In this parable, God speaks about Assyria as if it were a great tree to emphasize how great and powerful the Assyrians were. This parable continues until 31:9. Alternate translation: “Assyria was like a cedar” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parables]])
contextId.quoteString: Assyria was a cedar

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is background information for the events that follow. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: The cherubim stood & inner courtyard

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is used here to mark the beginning of a new part of the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-newevent]])
contextId.quoteString: Then it came about

contextId.occurrenceNote: This proverbs means that children experience the consequences of their parents’ actions. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-proverbs]])
contextId.quoteString: Fathers eat sour grapes, and the children’s teeth are made blunt

index.name: Introduction of New and Old Participants

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Yahweh is telling Ezekiel to speak to the mountains as if they were people so that the people of Israel would hear the words and know that Ezekiel’s words were for them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh speaks to those who will attack his people as if they could hear him and as if they were a sword that they would use in the attack. He does this to emphasize that he is in control of what is happening during the attack. The phrase “wherever your face is turned” is an idiom for “wherever you desire to go.” Alternate translation: “I tell those attacking with swords, ‘Strike to the right! … Attack in every direction.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: You, sword! Strike to the right! & Go wherever your face is turned.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks to the city of Jerusalem itself as if it were a woman who could hear him speak. Alternate translation: “come to Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: come to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: In all instances of this phrase, the writer refers to the people of Jerusalem as if they were the city itself, and of the city of Jerusalem as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “within this city” or “among you people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Within you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “stubborn faces” refer to the way they act on the outside, and the words “hard hearts” refer to the way they think and feel. Together they emphasize that the people of Israel would not change how they lived in order to obey God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: stubborn faces and hard hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: These mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: “very rebellious” or “very stubborn” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: strong browed and hard hearted

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “wicked deeds” means the same thing as “wickedness.” Alternate translation: “he does not stop doing wicked things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: he does not turn from his wickedness or from his wicked deeds

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “wrath” and “fury” mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh is very angry. Alternate translation: “because I will be very angry with you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: in wrath and fury

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are sounds people make when they feel very sad or grieved about something. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: groan and sigh

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words have similar meanings and emphasize that God will remove all the idols from Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: every detestable thing and every abomination

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “repent” and “turn way” mean basically the same thing. Together they strengthen the command to stop worshiping idols. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Repent and turn away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases refer to what the people of Israel have done. Alternate translation: “the way they live” or “the things they do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: their ways and their actions

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases share similar meanings. Yahweh speaks of when people founded the city as if it were the city’s birth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Your beginning and your birth

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases share similar meanings. They both refer to her growing and becoming taller. Alternate translation: “You matured and grew taller” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: You multiplied and became great

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean the same thing. Alternate translation: “completely naked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: naked and bare

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words “behavior” and “practices” mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: “copied the things that they did” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: copied their behavior and practices

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize how large and strong Pharaoh’s army is. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: his mighty army and a great company of men

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “poor” and “needy” share similar meanings and emphasize that these are people who cannot help themselves. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: the poor and needy

contextId.occurrenceNote: To “keep” Yahweh’s decrees is the same as to “obey them.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: keep my decrees and obey them

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean the same thing and emphasize that she will be completely uncovered. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: naked and bare

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the cup that causes horror and devastation.” The words “horror” and “devastation” share similar meanings here and emphasize how terrible her punishment will be. Alternate translation: “for what is in that cup causes horror and devastation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: the cup of horror and devastation

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “fury” means basically the same thing as and intensifies the word “anger.” Alternate translation: “my furious anger” or “my extreme anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: my anger and my fury

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “fury” and “anger” mean basically the same thing. Together they emphasize the intensity of his anger. Alternate translation: “Because I am extremely angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: In my fury and in my anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “ways” and “deeds” mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: “the things that they have done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: their ways and their deeds

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “ashamed” and “disgraced” share similar meanings. Together they emphasize the intensity of the shame. Alternate translation: “So be very ashamed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: So be ashamed and disgraced

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean the same thing and can be combined into a single phrase. Alternate translation: “you will plan to do something very evil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: plans will form in your heart & you will devise wicked schemes

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean the same thing and can be combined into a single phrase. Alternate translation: “take away all their valuable possessions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: capture booty and steal plunder

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases have similar meaning and can be combined into a single phrase. Alternate translation: “to take away their livestock and all their valuable possessions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: to take their livestock and property & to haul away much plunder

contextId.occurrenceNote: These refer to the same people. It can be stated as a single phrase. Alternate translation: “all your soldiers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: your troops and the soldiers

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meaning and emphasize the fact that this will really happen. Alternate translation: “is surely going to happen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: is coming & will take place

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. The Israelites will use the wood from the weapons as kindling for fires. Alternate translation: “to start fires” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: to kindle and make fires

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “to take” and “to plunder” mean the same thing. Gog intended to take Israel’s possessions, but Yahweh prevented him so that he was not able to do that. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: wanted to take & wanted to plunder

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases refer to the punishment that Yahweh will inflict upon Israel and are repeated for emphasis. They can be combined into a single phrase. Alternate translation: “the way that I will judge them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: my judgment that I perform and my hand that I have set against them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implicit information can be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “I said to you as you were lying in your blood” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: I said to you in your blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: The understood words may be supplied. Alternate translation: “have oppressed people … and plundered others” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: have oppressed & and plundered

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “same day” refers to the previous phrase “make my sanctuary unclean.” Alternate translation: “on the same day on which they make my sanctuary unclean, they defile my Sabbaths” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: on the same day they defile my Sabbaths

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “the sheep or goats” are left out of this phrase, but they are intended to be understood. Alternate translation: “the sheep or goats that are lost” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the lost

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “the sheep or goats” are left out of this phrase, but they are intended to be understood. Alternate translation: “the sheep or goats that are lost” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the lost

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sheep” is understood. Alternate translation: “the fat sheep and the strong sheep” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the fat and the strong

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “chamber” or “room” is understood from the previous phrase. The phrase “facing south” means that its door is on its south side, and “facing north” means that its door is on its north side. Alternate translation: “one room on the north side facing south, and the other room on the south side facing north” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: one on the north side facing south, and the other on the south side facing north

contextId.occurrenceNote: Another possible translation is, “every knee will flow with water,” a euphemism for all the people losing control of their bladders because they are so frightened. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: every knee will be weak as water

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this is a polite way to say the young woman was sleeping with the male figures. Alternate translation: “you slept with them” or (2) this is a metaphor in which Yahweh speaks of her worshiping the figures as if she were sleeping with them. Alternate translation: “you worshiped them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you did with them as a prostitute would do

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to accepting someone to sleep with her. Alternate translation: “you accept strangers into your bed instead of your husband” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: you accept strangers instead of your husband

contextId.occurrenceNote: The euphemism “to end them” refers to killing them. Alternate translation: “in order to kill them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: in order to end them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a euphemism that means to kill. Alternate translation: “kill” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: cut off

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a euphemism that means to kill. Alternate translation: “kill” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: cut off

contextId.occurrenceNote: “every knee will be as weak as water.” This is a euphemism for people being so afraid that they lose their bladder control and urinate on themselves. Alternate translation: “every leg will be wet with urine” or “everyone will lose control of their urine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: every knee will flow like water

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that a son sleeps with his father’s wife. Alternate translation: “there are men who sleep with their father’s wife” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: men uncover the nakedness of their father

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “fall” is a euphemism for “die.” The word “sword” is a metonym for soldiers who kill with swords. Alternate translation: “men will kill your survivors with their swords” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: your survivors will fall by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “fell” here is a euphemism for “died.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: fell by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This generalization refers to the places who are familiar with Jerusalem and represents the people who live in these places. Alternate translation: “of the people of every nearby land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: to all the lands

contextId.occurrenceNote: This does not refer to all of the people who live in these places, but rather to soldiers from there. Alternate translation: “soldiers from Babylon and all of Chaldea, Pekod, Shoa, and Koa, and all the soldiers of Assyria with them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: the Babylonians and all the Chaldeans, Pekod, Shoa, and Koa, and all the Assyrians with them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “all” here is a generalization. It means that many people will die. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: will all fall by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration to show that the Babylonians will kill very many Egyptians. There will be so many dead Egyptians that it will seem that their dead bodies cover all of the land of Egypt. Alternate translation: “kill so many people that it will seem like dead bodies are everywhere” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: fill the land with those who have been killed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “all” is probably a generalization that refers to the killing of large numbers of soldiers, and perhaps other people also. Alternate translation: “kill a very large number of people who live in Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: destroy all of its multitudes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “all” is a generalization that refers to all the wild animals that eat sheep. Alternate translation: “all the wild animals in the fields” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: all the beasts in the fields

contextId.occurrenceNote: “desolate forever.” This may be an exaggeration to emphasize the destruction. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: a perpetual desolation

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “the word of Yahweh came to” is used to introduce a special message from God. Alternate translation: “Yahweh gave a message to Ezekiel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the word of Yahweh came to Ezekiel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) Ezekiel is speaking of the “creatures” of verse 19 as if they were one creature. Alternate translation: “the spirit of the living creatures was in the wheels” or (2) Ezekiel is using an idiom. Alternate translation: “the spirit of life was in the wheels” or “the living spirit was in the wheels” or (3) the spirit in the creatures and in the wheels is the same. Alternate translation: “the same spirit that gave life to the creatures also gave life to the wheels” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the spirit of the living creature was in the wheels

contextId.occurrenceNote: “I bowed down to the ground” or “I lay on the ground.” Ezekiel did not fall by accident. He went down to the ground to show that he respected and feared Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I fell on my face

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “unwilling to change” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: strong browed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. Alternate translation: “Yahweh spoke this message” or “Yahweh spoke these words” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the word of Yahweh came

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom for holding someone responsible or guilty of murder. Alternate translation: “treat you as if you had murdered him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: require his blood from your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) clothing is a metonym for what a person feels, “will have no hope,” or (2) “will dress in clothes that show he is mourning.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: will dress in despair

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that he should look towards something. Alternate translation: “look up … looked up” or “turn your head and look … turned my head and looked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: lift up your eyes & lifted up my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the people were using the branches in false worship or (2) the people were using the branches to show rebellion against Yahweh. The words “branch to … noses” may be a literal tree branch and literal noses, or they could be the term for a hand gesture. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: putting the branch to their noses

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ezekiel is pleading with Yahweh not to destroy the remnant. Alternate translation: “please do not destroy all the remnant of Israel in the outpouring of your wrath on Jerusalem!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: will you destroy all the remnant of Israel in the outpouring of your wrath on Jerusalem?

contextId.occurrenceNote: “I bowed down to the ground” or “I lay on the ground.” Ezekiel did not fall by accident. He went down to the ground to show that he respected and feared Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: I fell on my face

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that many days have passed. Alternate translation: “Many days have passed” or “Time has gone by” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The days are prolonged

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that Yahweh does what he says. Alternate translation: “I do the things that I say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I carry out the words that I speak

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom refers to the period of time in which a person lives. Alternate translation: “while you are alive” or “during you lifetime” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: in your days

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “spirit” represents the thoughts and ideas of the person. To “follow” here is an idiom that means to do what their own ideas suggest for them to do. Alternate translation: “who act according to their own ideas” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: who follow their own spirit

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a phrase used to refer to anything the prophet may have said. Your language may have another way to say this. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Such and such

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom refers to women who belong to the same people group as Ezekiel does. Alternate translation: “women of Israel” or “your countrywomen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: daughters of your people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means to remember. Alternate translation: “remember” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: call to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means to remember. Alternate translation: “remember” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: call to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means to remember. Alternate translation: “remember everything” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: call everything to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “the word of Yahweh came” is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. Alternate translation: “Yahweh spoke to me again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The word of Yahweh came to me again

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “teeth are made blunt” refers to the sour taste in one’s mouth that is a result of eating unripe or sour fruit. Alternate translation: “the children get a sour taste in their mouths” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the children’s teeth are made blunt

contextId.occurrenceNote: For righteousness to be on a person is an idiom that means the person is responsible for that righteousness. Alternate translation: “The one who acts rightly will be responsible for his own righteousness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The righteousness of the one who acts rightly will be on himself

contextId.occurrenceNote: For wickedness to be on a person is an idiom that means the person is responsible for that wickedness. Alternate translation: “the wicked person will be responsible for his own wickedness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the wickedness of the wicked will be on himself

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “call to mind” means to remember. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will not remember all the transgressions that he has committed and will not hold them against him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: All the transgressions that he has committed will not be called to mind against him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “call to mind” means to remember. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will not remember all the righteousness that he had done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
