contextId.quoteString: All the righteousness that he had done will not be called to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means to sing a lamentation. Alternate translation: “sing a lamentation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: take up a lamentation

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “them” refers to the nations. The idiom “in their eyes” refers to being in a position where people can see. Alternate translation: “I revealed myself to them, in their presence” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I made myself known to them, in their eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means to remember. Alternate translation: “you will remember” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: you will call to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh tells Ezekiel to groan as a sign to accompany his message. He tells him to groan deeply as if his abdomen was in great pain. “groan deeply as if your loins were in great pain” or “groan deeply with great sorrow” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: groan as your loins break

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “cannot resist” or “is destroyed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: does not last

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “whom Yahweh will now punish” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: whose day of punishment has come

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases “day of” and “time of” are idioms. Alternate translation: “for the time has come for them to be punished and for their iniquity to end” or “for the time has come for me to punish them and for them to no longer be able to commit wickedness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: whose day of punishment has come and whose time of iniquity is about to end

contextId.occurrenceNote: The images of days being brought to a close and years coming to an end are both idioms representing ending by death or by destruction. By saying that Jerusalem has brough her days to a close, Yahweh implies that Jerusalem would soon be destroyed because of the people’s sin. Alternate translation: “Because of these things you have done, you are approaching the end of your time” or “You are bringing your existence to an end” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: You have drawn your days to a close, and the end of your years has come

contextId.occurrenceNote: Rain is used as an example of God’s blessing. Alternate translation: “There is no blessing on the day of wrath” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: There is no rain on the day of wrath

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “they talked about her disgrace” or “she had a bad reputation among them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: they executed judgment on her

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “so she rejected them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: so she turned herself away from them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “will attack you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: will come against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “they have murdered people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: there is blood on their hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “condemn” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: pass judgment

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “who murder people … murderers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: who shed blood & blood is on their hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “raise up” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “gather a large group of people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: raise up a company

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “kill them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: cut them down

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “cause you to accept responsibility for your shameful behavior” or “punish you for your shameful behavior” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: set your shameful behavior against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “has not gone out of her” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “but the fire did not burn away her corrosion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: but her corrosion has not gone out of her by the fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “from within themselves” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “The Philistines hate Judah and have tried to take revenge against it by their own strength again and again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The Philistines have taken vengeance with malice and from within themselves they tried to destroy Judah again and again

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “I will destroy” or “I will get rid of” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will cut off

contextId.occurrenceNote: “it will devour you.” The fire is spoken of here as if it was eating him up. Alternate translation: “it will burn you up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: it will consume you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means burning up until only ashes are left. Alternate translation: “burn you up to ashes” or “burn you up completely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: turn you into ashes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “set fire” is an idiom meaning “start a fire.” Alternate translation: “I will start a fire in Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Then I will set fire in Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “went down to Sheol” means “died.” Alternate translation: “On the day that the cedar died” or “On the day that the cedar was chopped down” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: On the day when the cedar went down to Sheol

contextId.occurrenceNote: “that were already deep down in the ground.” This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “that had already died and are now in Sheol” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: in the lowest parts of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “went down … to Sheol” is an idiom that means to die. Alternate translation: “those trees of Lebanon also died and went down to Sheol with the cedar” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: they also went down with it to Sheol

contextId.occurrenceNote: “to the places under the ground.” When people died, they were put in the ground. So “bring them down … to the lowest earth” means “make them die.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the lowest earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “I will not think about” or “I will not recall” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will not call to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “call to mind” is an idiom that means to remember. The phrase “will be called” can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “will I think about” or “will I recall” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: will be called to mind for him

contextId.occurrenceNote: “you look to your idols” This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “you worship your idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: you lift up your eyes towards your idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “fall by the sword” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “enemies will kill the ones living in the ruins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the ones in the ruins will fall by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that is used to introduce a special message from God. Alternate translation: “listen to Yahweh’s message” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: hear the word of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: “listen to Yahweh’s message.” This is an idiom that is used to introduce a special message from God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: hear the word of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “require … from their hand” is an idiom that means to hold or consider someone responsible for something. Alternate translation: “I will hold them responsible for all the bad things that happen to my flock” or “I will punish them for all the bad things they let happen to my flock” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will require my flock from their hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “set over” is an idiom that means to cause a person to rule someone else. Alternate translation: “I will assign one shepherd to be in charge of my sheep and the goats” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will set over them one shepherd

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “I … am with them” is an idiom that means Yahweh helps them. Alternate translation: “I, Yahweh their God, am helping them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I, Yahweh their God, am with them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “be fruitful” is an idiom that means to have many children and descendants. Alternate translation: “they will become very many people and have very many children” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: they will multiply and be fruitful

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that refers to killing someone. Alternate translation: “because they made the blood of many people spill onto the land” or “because they murdered many people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: for the blood that they poured out on the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: “from the four directions that the wind can blow in.” This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “from every direction” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: from the four winds

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means “I am your enemy.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I am against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “face” refers to Yahweh’s help and protection. Alternate translation: “I stopped protecting them and taking care of them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I hid my face from them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “no longer hide my face” is an idiom that means Yahweh will not continue to abandon Israel to exile in Babylon. Alternate translation: “I will no longer abandon them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will no longer hide my face from them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means “pay attention to” or “think about.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: fix your mind on

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “consumed” here means “completely destroyed.” Alternate translation: “completely destroyed them because I was angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: consumed them with my anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase means “so that I will bless your family and everything that belongs to you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: so that blessing may rest on your house

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is used to mock the king’s scepter by calling it a “rod.” Alternate translation: “such scepter” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: such rod

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is speaking with irony. Normally people sacrificed animals to God. Here, God is sacrificing people to animals. Alternate translation: “as if they were male sheep, lambs, goats, and bulls” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: they will be rams, lambs, goats, and bulls

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases mean that Ezekiel will speak. In the second phrase it is stated in negative form to emphasize that he will speak. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
contextId.quoteString: you will speak—you will no longer be silent

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a merism that refers to the area to the north, and to the south, and all places in between. Alternate translation: “in every direction” or “everywhere” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: from the south to the north

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to all of Egypt. Where these places are can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “throughout all of Egypt, from Migdol in the north to Syene in the south and the borders of Cush further south” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: from the Migdol to Syene and the borders of Cush

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ezekiel names towns on the borders of Egypt in order to refer to all of Egypt. Alternate translation: “In all of Egypt” or “From the northern border of Egypt to the southern border of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: From Migdol to Syene

contextId.occurrenceNote: Rocks never change and become soft, and these people never change and become sorry when they do evil things. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: hard hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words describe the people of Israel who will not treat Ezekiel kindly when he tells them what God says. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: briers and thorns and & scorpions

contextId.occurrenceNote: A hard face is a metaphor for being stubborn. Alternate translation: “I have made you as stubborn as they are” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have made your face as hard as their faces

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ezekiel speaks of his anger at Yahweh as if there were a bad taste in his mouth because Yahweh had forced him to eat something that tasted bad. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: bitterness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ezekiel speaks of being sad and tired because Yahweh had commanded him to do things he did not want to do as if Yahweh were pushing him down into the ground. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for the hand of Yahweh was powerfully pressing on me

contextId.occurrenceNote: God told Ezekiel to warn the people of Israel just as a watchman would warn the people of a city if enemies were coming, so that they could prepare and be safe. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: watchman

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “make something bad happen to him” or (2) “cause him to sin openly.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: set a stumbling block before him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bonds are ropes or chains that keep a person from moving. It is not clear whether the word “bonds” is a metaphor for something Yahweh does that is as if he had bound Ezekiel or if he is using literal, physical ropes. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I am placing bonds on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The supply is called a staff because some people need a staff to walk and do their work, and people need bread to live. Bread represents all kinds of food. Alternate translation: “the supply of food” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the staff of bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “waste away” is usually used of flesh or wood rotting. Here it is a metaphor for wicked people becoming thin and dying because they have no food. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: waste away

contextId.occurrenceNote: “from there a fire will spread out and burn up all the people of Israel.” Yahweh speaks of how he will punish Israel as if he were going to set fire to a house and of the people of Israel as if they were the family that lives in that house but were at that time outside the house. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: from there a fire will go out to all the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Walking is a metaphor for the way a person lives. Alternate translation: “have not lived according to my statutes” or “have not obeyed my statutes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: have not walked in my statutes

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Wrath” is spoken of as if it were an arrow that Yahweh was shooting at the people. Alternate translation: “I am angry, and I will punish you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I am sending out my wrath on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The way a person lives is spoken of as a path on which one walks. Alternate translation: “I will punish you for the things you have done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will bring your ways upon you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses the terms “pour out” and “fill up” to speak of his anger as if it were water that he poured out into a jar. These phrases emphasize that Yahweh will punish the people severely. Alternate translation: “I will punish you severely because I am very angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: I will pour out my fury against you and fill up my wrath upon you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “The people of Israel have grown very proud” or (2) “The people of Israel have become very violent and very proud.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The rod has blossomed, arrogance has budded

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “consume” is a metaphor for “totally destroy.” Alternate translation: “and most of the people in the city will die from hunger and sickness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: while famine and plague will consume those in the city

contextId.occurrenceNote: Terror is spoken of as if it were clothing. Alternate translation: “everyone will see how terrified they are” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: terror will cover them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The city is spoken of as if it were a container, and violence is spoken of as an object that can be put in a container. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **violence**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “violence is everywhere in the city” or “many people in the city are doing violent things to others” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: the city is full of violence

contextId.occurrenceNote: This should be translated literally, as Ezekiel later sees something like a hand. Others may choose to consider the hand a metaphor for Yahweh’s presence or power. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the hand of the Lord Yahweh again fell upon me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “land” is spoken of as if it were a container filled with blood. Here “blood” is metonym for murder. And “city” is spoken of as if it were a container and “perversions” were the contents inside of it. Alternate translation: “All over the land people are killing innocent people, and all over the city people are doing wicked things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The land is full of blood and the city full of perversions

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people speak of themselves as if they were good cuts of meat and of the city as if it were a pot in which the meat was stored or cooked. The metaphor suggests that they are important and safe within the city. Alternate translation: “This city is like a pot that will protect us as a pot protects meat” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: this city is the pot, and we are the meat

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ezekiel speaks of the Spirit of Yahweh inspiring and empowering him to prophesy as if the Spirit of Yahweh fell upon him. Alternate translation: “the Spirit of Yahweh empowered me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the Spirit of Yahweh fell on me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of obeying his statutes as if it were walking in them, like person would walk along a road. Alternate translation: “the one whose statutes you have not obeyed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the one whose statutes you have not walked in

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of dwelling among the people who are in exile as if he were a sanctuary for them. Alternate translation: “I have been with them” or “I have been like their place of worship” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have been a sanctuary for them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of all of the Israelites who are in exile as if they are one person, with one heart and one spirit. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will give them one heart & give them a heart of flesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people being stubborn as if they had a stone heart and of their being willingly obedient as if they had a heart of flesh. He speaks of causing them to become willingly obedient as if he were exchanging those two hearts. Alternate translation: “I will cause them to stop being stubborn and instead cause them to obey me willingly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will take out the heart of stone from their flesh and give them a heart of flesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of obeying his statutes as if it were walking in them, like a person would walk along a road. Alternate translation: “they will obey my statutes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they will walk in my statutes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of a person’s conduct as if it were the person walking. Alternate translation: “those who conduct their lives out of devotion to their detestable things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: those who walk with affection toward their detestable things

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ezekiel speaks of the vision ending as if the vision was an object that had been upon him and then left him. Alternate translation: “the vision that I had seen ended” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the vision that I had seen went up from upon me

contextId.occurrenceNote: People being unable to understand Yahweh’s message and what he is doing is spoken of as if the people were unable physically to see and hear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they have eyes to see but they do not see & they have ears to hear but do not listen

contextId.occurrenceNote: People being able to understand Yahweh’s message and what he is doing is spoken of as if the people were able physically to see. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Perhaps they will begin to see

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “sign” refers to something that communicates a special warning to those who see it. Yahweh speaks of Ezekiel and his actions as being this warning. Alternate translation: “have made you to be a warning” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: have set you as a sign

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “sign” refers to something that communicates a special warning to those who see it. Ezekiel speaks of himself and his actions as being this warning. Alternate translation: “I am a warning to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I am a sign to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of enabling the Chaldeans to capture the prince as if he himself were catching the prince in a trap that he had set. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will spread out my net over him and he will be caught in my snare

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In these verses, Yahweh speaks of the false security that the prophets have given to the people by speaking of peace as if the prophets had built a poorly-constructed wall and covered it over with white paint in order to make it look good. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the prophets deceiving the people and getting them to believe lies as if the prophets had led the people away from the path upon which they should have been walking. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they led my people astray

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “a wall” stands for peace and security that the false prophets told the people that Yahweh was promising to give them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they are building a wall that they will paint with whitewash

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh refers to the judgment that he will send upon the people as if it were a severe storm that breaks down the wall. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will send hailstones to make it fall down, and a windstorm wind to break it down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh refers to the judgment that he will send upon the people as if it were a severe storm that breaks down the wall. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will bring a windstorm & completely destroy it.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “in the middle of it all” refers to the stones of the wall that Yahweh will break down. He speaks of destroying the people in his judgment as if the wall would crush them to death when he breaks it down. Alternate translation: “all of its stones will crush you to death” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you will be annihilated in the middle of it all

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of these women using beauty, mystery, and lies to deceive people as if the people were animals that the women hunted down and trapped with their charms. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that they use to hunt down people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: used to hunt down people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of these women using their magic charms to deceive people as if the people were birds that the women trapped with those charms. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the magic charms that you have used to ensnare the people’s lives as if they were birds

contextId.occurrenceNote: To stop doing something is referred to as turning in a different direction. Alternate translation: “stop what he is doing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: turn from his way

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the elders committing themselves to worshiping idols as if the elders had “taken their idols into their hearts.” Alternate translation: “have devoted themselves to idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: have taken their idols into their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the idols that the elders worship as if they were blocks over which the elders stumble, and of being determined to worship those idols as if they had placed those stumbling blocks in front of their faces. Alternate translation: “have resolutely determined to worship the things that lead to iniquity” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: have put the stumbling block of their iniquity before their own faces

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “sign” refers to something that communicates a special warning to those who see it. The word proverb refers to what people will say about that sign when they see it. Alternate translation: “I will make that man to be a warning and a proverb” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: make him a sign and a proverb

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of causing a person no longer to belong to his people as if he were cutting that person off from the people, like a person would cut a branch from a tree. Alternate translation: “I will cause him no longer to belong to my people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will cut him off from the midst of my people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people no longer worshiping him as if they were to wander away from him and no longer follow him. Alternate translation: “will no longer stop worshiping me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will no longer wander away from following me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of killing people and animals as if he were cutting them off, like a person would cut a branch from a tree. Alternate translation: “kill both man and beast in the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: cut off both man and beast from the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of killing people and animals as if it were cutting them off, like a person would cut a branch from a tree. Alternate translation: “kill both man and beast in the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: cut off both man and beast from it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of expressing his fury as if his fury were a liquid that he pours out from a container. Alternate translation: “I will express my fury” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: pour out my fury

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of killing people and animals as if he were cutting them off, like a person would cut a branch from a tree. Alternate translation: “kill both man and beast” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: cut off both man and beast

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of killing people and animals as if it were cutting them off, like a person would cut a branch from a tree. The word “her” refers to Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “to kill both man and beast in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to cut off both man and beast from her

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the punishment that he will afflict upon the people as if it were a fire that burns them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Though they come out from the fire, yet the fire will consume them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of fire burning things as if the fire consumed them. Alternate translation: “the fire will destroy them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the fire will consume them

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In this chapter, Yahweh speaks about Jerusalem as if the city were his unfaithful bride. He describes her growth from infancy to adulthood. The city represents the people who live there. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Amorites and Hittites were both pagan people groups who lived in the land before the people of Israel conquered it. Yahweh speaks of Jerusalem’s father and mother belonging to these people groups to express that she was born into idolatry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: your father was an Amorite, and your mother was a Hittite

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the woman, who represents Jerusalem, is spoken of as if she had become the finest of all jewels, that is, as if she had become the most beautiful of all women. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you became the jewel of jewels

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of Jerusalem as if the city were an unfaithful wife who sleeps with other men in exchange for payment. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: acted like a prostitute

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of Jerusalem’s immoral actions as if they were liquids and of committing those actions repeatedly as if it were pouring those liquids from a container. Alternate translation: “you repeatedly committed your acts of prostitution” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you poured out your acts of prostitution

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the beginning of a road as if it were its head. Alternate translation: “at the beginning of every road” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: at the head of every road

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of stopping the supply of food as if it were cutting off the food. Alternate translation: “stop your food supply” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: cut off your food

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh speaks of the cities of Philistia as if they were the daughters of the Philistines. The cities represent the people who live there. Alternate translation: “the Philistine people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the daughters of the Philistines

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of Jerusalem’s lust as if it were liquid and of committing actions repeatedly to gratify that lust as if it were pouring that liquid from a container. Alternate translation: “you repeatedly committed actions to gratify your lust” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you have poured out your lust

contextId.occurrenceNote: The way a person lives is spoken of as if the person were walking on a path. Alternate translation: “You not only acted like them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You not only walked in their ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh describes Sodom as a rich woman who has more than enough food and lives in security. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: arrogant in her leisure, careless and unconcerned about anything

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh speaks of the cities of Edom and Philistia as if they were the daughters of Edom and of the Philistines. The cities represent the people who live there. Alternate translation: “the Edomite people and to all the Philistine people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the daughters of Edom and to all the daughters of the Philistines

contextId.occurrenceNote: The kingdom being small and weak is spoken of as if it were lowly and being large and powerful as if it lifted itself up. Alternate translation: “so the kingdom might remain small and not become great” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: so the kingdom might become lowly and not lift itself up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of enabling the enemy army to capture the king as if he were trapping the king in a net. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will spread my net out over him, and he will be caught in my hunting net

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of a person obeying his statutes as if the statutes were a path in which the person walks. Alternate translation: “that man obeys my statutes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: that man walks in my statutes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of obeying his statutes as if his statutes were a path in which the person walks. Alternate translation: “obeys my statutes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: walks according to my statutes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of a person being responsible for or guilty of iniquity as if the iniquity were an object that the person carries. Alternate translation: “Why is the son not responsible for the iniquity of his father?” or “Why is the son not guilty of the iniquity of his father?” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Why does the son not bear the iniquity of his father?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of a person’s lifestyle or behavior as if it were a way on which the person walks. The idiom “to turn away” from something means to stop doing that thing. Alternate translation: “not in his ceasing to live the way that he lives” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: not in his turning away from his way

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the person thinking about and understanding something as if the person were seeing it. Alternate translation: “he has considered” or “he has understood” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he has seen

contextId.occurrenceNote: Actions or behaviors are spoken of as if they were a way or path that a person travels. Alternate translation: “The Lord does not act fairly … How do I not act fairly … It is you who do not act fairly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The way of the Lord is not fair & How is my way not fair & It is your ways that are not fair

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of a person’s actions as if the person were walking along a path. Alternate translation: “according to his actions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: according to his ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of “transgressions” causing people to rebel against him as if they were blocks over which the people stumble. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: turn away from all your transgressions so that they will not be stumbling blocks of iniquity against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people determining to stop committing transgressions as if the transgressions were objects, such as clothing, that they removed and threw away. Alternate translation: “Get rid of all of the transgressions that you have committed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Throw away from yourselves all of the transgressions that you have committed

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Yahweh tells Ezekiel to speak to the people of Israel. He tells a story where the nation of Israel is a lioness and some of the past kings in the kingdom of Judah are her cubs. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Yahweh speaks of the nation of Israel as though it was the mother of the leaders of Israel. Here he begins to tell a story where she is a prosperous vine. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The very dry land is spoken of as if it were thirsty. Alternate translation: “in a very dry land of drought” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: in a land of drought and thirst

contextId.occurrenceNote: “It was a land where plenty of milk and honey flowed.” Yahweh speaks of the land being good for animals and plants as if the milk and honey from those animals and plants were flowing through the land. Alternate translation: “It was land that was excellent for raising livestock and growing crops” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: It was flowing with milk and honey

contextId.occurrenceNote: The lands in which people live are spoken of as if they are jewelry or other things that are pleasant to look at. Alternate translation: “the most beautiful of all lands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the most beautiful ornament among all the lands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people worshiping the detestable things as if they had placed those idols in front of their eyes. Alternate translation: “the detestable things that he worships” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the detestable things from before his eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who is not acceptable for God’s purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not make yourselves unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people worshiping the detestable things as if they had placed those idols in front of their eyes. Alternate translation: “the detestable things that he worshiped” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the detestable things from before his eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of expressing his fury by punishing them as if his fury were a liquid that he poured out on them. Alternate translation: “to act against them in my fury” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to pour out my fury upon them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: “in the opinion” or “in the judgment” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: in the eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of obeying his statutes as if the statutes were a path along which a person walks. Alternate translation: “They did not obey my statutes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They did not walk in my statutes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of obeying his statutes as if they were a path along which a person walks. Alternate translation: “did not obey my statutes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: did not walk in my statutes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of a person obeying statutes as if the statutes were paths along with a person walks. Alternate translation: “Do not obey the statutes of your parents” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not walk in the statutes of your fathers

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of a person obeying statutes as if the statutes were paths along with a person walks. Alternate translation: “Do not obey the statutes of your parents … obey my statutes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: walk in my statutes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of a person obeying his statutes as if the statutes were a path along which the person walks. Alternate translation: “They did not obey my statutes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They did not walk in my statutes

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who is not acceptable for God’s purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Why do you make yourselves unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of expressing his fury as if the fury were a liquid that he pours out on the people. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “fury that I will pour out on you” or “I will express my fury towards you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: fury that will be poured out on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the practice of a shepherd counting and inspecting his sheep as the sheep walked under his staff. This could mean: (1) Yahweh will count his people whom he gathers from the nations to ensure that they are all present. Alternate translation: “I will count you carefully as a shepherd counts his sheep” or (2) Yahweh will inspect each person as they pass under his staff in order to separate the faithful from the unfaithful. Alternate translation: “I will inspect you carefully as a shepherd inspects his sheep” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will cause you to pass under my rod

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the best things among all that they give to him as if they were “firstfruits.” Alternate translation: “the best of your contributions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the firstfruits of your tribute

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of his people worshiping him as they should as if the people themselves were the incense offering. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will accept you like fragrant incense

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who is not acceptable for God’s purposes is spoken of as if the person were defiled. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you defiled yourselves

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: “you will hate yourselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you will despise yourselves in your own eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh causing these people to die as if he actually killed them with his own sword. Alternate translation: “I am opposed to you, and it will be as though I pull my sword from its sheath to kill both the righteous and the wicked people among you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will draw my sword from its sheath and cut off both the righteous person and the wicked person from you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh causing these people to die as if he actually killed them with his own sword. Alternate translation: “it will be as though I pull my sword from its sheath and strike” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: my sword will go out from its sheath against

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh causing people to die as if he actually killed them with his own sword. Alternate translation: “it is as though I, Yahweh, have struck people with my sword” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: that I, Yahweh, have drawn my sword from its sheath

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of people becoming fearful in their spirits as if their spirits were about to faint. Alternate translation: “Everyone will be fearful in their inner being” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Every spirit will grow faint

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the leaders of Israel being killed with a sword as if they are thrown against the sword. Alternate translation: “They are killed with the sword along with my people” or “The sword will kill them along with my people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They are thrown against the sword with my people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of causing the people to be so terrified that it is as if their hearts were melting. Alternate translation: “to fill them with terror” or “to cause them to be terrified” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to melt their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the sword of Yahweh represents men with swords that are to attack Jerusalem. Also, the word “slaughter” can be expressed as a verb. Alternate translation: “placed soldiers armed with swords at their gates, ready to slaughter the people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: set the sword for slaughter

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sword of Yahweh represents the men with swords that are to attack Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “released to slaughter the people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it is grasped for slaughter

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: “in the thoughts of the people in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: in the eyes of the ones in Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the sword of Yahweh which is a metaphor for the soldiers that Yahweh uses to kill a large number of people who have been disobedient to him. Alternate translation: “Swords! My soldiers have drawn their swords! They are sharpened for the slaughter” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: A sword, a sword is drawn! It is sharpened for the slaughter

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of visions being false and meaningless as if they were empty containers. Alternate translation: “visions that are not true” or “false visions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: empty visions

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Later the sword will be put back in its sheath.” This speaks of the soldiers withdrawing from attacking Jerusalem, by saying that Yahweh’s sword is put back in its sheath. Alternate translation: “But later the soldiers will return their swords to their sheaths, for the time of slaughter will be over” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Return the sword to its sheath

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh punishing the Babylonians because of his indignation against them as if his indignation were a liquid that he poured out of a container upon them. Alternate translation: “I will punish you because of indignation against you” or “Out of my anger I will punish you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will pour out my indignation on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares Yahweh’s rage to a consuming fire. Alternate translation: “I will bring my rage upon you like a blazing fire” or “I will punish you in my fierce anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will fan the fire of my rage against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “blood” is a metonym for murder. Alternate translation: “where many people murder their neighbors” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: that pours out blood in her midst

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of murdering people as pouring out blood. Alternate translation: “because you murdered innocent people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: by the blood that you have poured out

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person whom God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of murdering people as pouring out blood. Alternate translation: “to murder people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to pour out blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person whom God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. Women were considered to be unclean during their menstrual period. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of murdering people as pouring out blood. Alternate translation: “to murder people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to pour out blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Refusing to obey Yahweh is like forgetting that he exists. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you have forgotten me

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: uncleanness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “nations” refer to the people who live in those places. The “eyes” represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: “So the nations will consider you unclean” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: So you will become unclean in the eyes of the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Dross is the impurities that are left over after silver or gold has been purified in a furnace. Here Yahweh speaks of the people being worthless to him as if they were dross. Alternate translation: “has become as worthless to me as dross” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: has become dross to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh continues to speaks about how the people have become worthless to him as if they were dross. Alternate translation: “All of them are as worthless as the leftover of bronze and tin, and iron and lead that remain after you melt silver in the furnace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: All of them are the leftovers of bronze and tin & like the dross of silver in your furnace

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the image of a person gathering the metals in the furnace and blowing the fire to make it hotter. Yahweh speaks of the greatness of his wrath as if it were a fire that he was blowing to make it hotter. Alternate translation: “I will gather you, and my wrath will be like a fire that I will blow on you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will gather you and blow on you the fire of my wrath

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of punishing the people as if his wrath were a liquid that he would pour on them. Alternate translation: “have punished you in my anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: have poured out my wrath on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: not been cleansed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the people ignoring and not observing the Sabbath and if they were hiding their eyes from the Sabbath” Alternate translation: “They ignore my Sabbaths” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They hide their eyes from my Sabbaths

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the prophets trying to hide these sins as if they were something that they could paint over with whitewash. Alternate translation: “It is like her prophets have painted over their sins with whitewash” or “Their prophets try to hide these evil things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Her prophets have painted them over with whitewash

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Yahweh compares the leaders of Jerusalem to a wall and himself to an invading army. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of a man who would take responsibility to pray for the people and to lead them to repentance as if that man were to build a wall to protect the people from Yahweh. Alternate translation: “a man from among them who would act like he built a wall” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a man from them who would build up a wall

contextId.occurrenceNote: Its “breach” refers to a gap in the wall. This speaks of the man defending the people before Yahweh as if he were a warrior standing in the breach to defend the city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: stand before me in its breach

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh punishing the people as if his indignation were a liquid that he poured out on them. Alternate translation: “I will punish the people because of my indignation for them” or “I will punish the people because of my anger against them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: pour out my indignation upon them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of how harsh Yahweh’s judgement is by comparing it to a fire. Here destroying the people is referred to as “finishing” them. Alternate translation: “I will destroy them with my wrath which is as intense as a blazing fire” or “I will destroy them with my wrath” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: I will finish them with the fire of my indignation

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Oholah represents Samaria, and Oholibah represents Jerusalem.” In this metaphor Samaria is spoken of as if it were Oholah and Jerusalem is spoken of as if it were Oholibah. This speaks of how these cities were unfaithful to Yahweh as if they were unfaithful wives. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Their names mean this: Oholah means Samaria, and Oholibah means Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of lust as if it were a large amount of water that they were pouring out on her. Alternate translation: “to act lustfully toward her” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: poured out their lust upon her

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh speaks of causing the armies to attack them because he is angry with them as if his anger where something that he was placing upon them. Alternate translation: Because I am very jealous for you, I will cause them to act furiously towards you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For I will set my jealous anger on you, and they will deal with you in fury

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a way to refer to a person turning their head to look at something. Here looking represents desire. Alternate translation: “You will not look toward them with longing” or “You will not desire these things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You will not lift up your eyes toward them with longing

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Oholibah’s punishment that she will receive as if it were a cup of wine. Alternate translation: “so I will cause you to be punished in the same way as your sister” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: so I will put her cup of punishment into your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of being very drunk and full of sorrow as if drunkenness and sorrow were things that filled her body. Alternate translation: “You will become very drunk and very sad” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You will be filled with drunkenness and sorrow

contextId.occurrenceNote: Oholibah’s sister Oholah represents Samaria. Samaria is called by it’s name but still referred to as a sister. The cup is a symbol for the punishment that she received. Alternate translation: “for this is the same cup of punishment that your sister, who represents Samaria, drank” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the cup of your sister Samaria

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of Oholibah rejecting him as if he were an object that she had thrown behind her back and forgotten. Alternate translation: “rejected me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: thrown me away behind your back

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Yahweh again refers to the cities of Jerusalem and Samaria as if they were two prostitutes. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh continues to compare Jerusalem to a cooking pot. Alternate translation: “it is like a cooking pot” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a cooking pot

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person whom God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: uncleanness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “she” refers to the cooking pot. This is the cooking pot that is metaphorical for Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “Jerusalem has become tired” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: She has become weary

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “melt away” is a metaphor for wasting away and dying. Alternate translation: “you will become very thin and slowly die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you will melt away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The abstract nouns “joy” and “pride” can be translated as noun phrases. Alternate translation: “which is what they are joyful about and what they are proud of” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: which is their joy, their pride

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the enemy army conquering the land of Ammon and taking possession of the land and everything in it as if the enemy were taking the people of Ammon as their possession. It is not implied here that the enemy took the people of Ammon as slaves. Alternate translation: “I will cause an army from a land that is east of you to come and conquer you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I am giving you to a people in the east as their possession

contextId.occurrenceNote: “I will hit you with my powerful hand.” Here Yahweh speaks of punishing the people as if he were literally hitting them with his hand. Alternate translation: “I will punish you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will strike you with my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh speaks of allowing the armies from the east to conquer Ammon as if Ammon were a possession that he was giving them. Alternate translation: “I will allow the armies to conquer them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will give them up as a possession

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Tyre use these words to refer to Jerusalem as if it were a city gate through which traders from the surrounding nations pass. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Armies have broken down the gates of the people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The gates of the people are broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: This metaphor represents the princes trembling enough to seem like it was their clothing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They will clothe themselves with trembling

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents being restored to the city’s former existence. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: stand in the land of the living

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

“Your” and “you” in these verses refer to Tyre. The city of Tyre is described here and in the following verses as if it were a beautiful ship. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Tyre’s abundance is spoken of as if it was a ship that was full of cargo. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you were filled up, heavily laden with cargo

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

The words “you” and “your” in these verses refer to Tyre. The city of Tyre is described here and in the following verses as if it were a wrecked ship. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: “I will sit on the throne of the gods.” Here sitting in the seat of the gods represents claiming to be in the same exalted position as if he were one of the gods. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will sit in the seat of the gods

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here being in the hand of someone represents being under their control. Alternate translation: “under the control of” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: in the hand of

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the king of Tyre as if he were a container that was filled up with violence. The king is a synecdoche for himself and his people If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **violence**, you can express the same idea with an adjective such as “violent.” Alternate translation: “you and your people became completely violent” or “you and your peoplewere completely violent” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: you were filled with violence

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “blood” refers to the blood of the people of Sidon and represents those whom their enemies would kill. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: blood in your streets

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the briars and thorns represent what would cause suffering and pain. Alternate translation: “people anywhere around the house of Israel who wound them like briars, hurt them like thorns, and despise them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: pricking briars and painful thorns for the house of Israel from all those around her who despise her people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “they” refers to the inhabitants of Egypt. A reed stalk is unreliable because it is easily broken. Yahweh speaks of them as a reed stalk because the people of Israel relied on the Egyptians to help them in war, but the Egyptians did not help them. Alternate translation: “they have been as unreliable as a reed stalk” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they have been a reed stalk

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Israel relying on Egypt as if they were taking hold of a reed stalk in order to use it as a crutch. Alternate translation: “When they relied on you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: When they took hold of you in their hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Because Egypt did not help the Israelites, the Israelites could not defend themselves against their enemy, the Babylonians. God speaks of the Israelites being unable to defend themselves as if their legs were unsteady. Alternate translation: “you caused them to be like people whose legs are unsteady” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you caused their legs to be unsteady

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “cut off man and beast” is a metaphor for destroying the people and animals. God would do this by causing the enemy army to do it. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will cut off both man and beast from you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “fortunes of Egypt” is a metaphor for the people of Egypt who had been taken away to other countries. Alternate translation: “I will bring back the people of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will restore the fortunes of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “lowly” represents unimportant. Alternate translation: “an unimportant kingdom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a lowly kingdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “lowliest” represents least important. Alternate translation: “the least important of the kingdoms” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the lowliest of the kingdoms

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “be lifted up” represents becoming important. Alternate translation: “it will not become important again among the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it will not be lifted up any more among the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: “I will make them small.” Here “diminish them” represents making Egypt weak or unimportant. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will diminish them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “payment” represents the valuable things that Nebuchadnezzar’s army would steal from Tyre as a reward for defeating it. God speaks of these things as if they were what God would pay them for working for him. Alternate translation: “he and his army did not get any valuable things from Tyre as reward” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he and his army received no payment from Tyre

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of causing the army of Babylon to defeat Egypt as if God were giving Egypt to Nebuchadnezzar. Alternate translation: “I will cause the army of Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, to defeat Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I am giving the land of Egypt to Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of these things that Nebuchadnezzar’s army would take as if they were what God would pay them for working for him. Alternate translation: “his army will receive those things as if they were payment” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: that will be his army’s wages

contextId.occurrenceNote: Dark storm clouds represent danger and fear. Alternate translation: “It will be like a day with dark clouds” or “It will be frightening like a day with dark clouds” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a day of clouds

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents Egypt no longer being proud of their strength. The reason that they will not be proud is that they will no longer be strong. Alternate translation: “Egypt will no longer be proud about being strong” or “Egypt will no longer have the strength that they were so proud of” (See:[[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the pride of her strength will go down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being “among” the ruined cities represents being ruined like the ruined cities of other countries. Alternate translation: “their cities will be ruined like the cities of other countries” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: their cities will be among all the ruined cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will give the Babylonians control over Egypt just as a person who sells something gives the one who buys it control over that thing. Alternate translation: “I will give control of the land to wicked men” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will sell the land into the hand of wicked men

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “put terror on the land” represents causing the people of the land to be very afraid. Alternate translation: “I will make the people of Egypt very afraid” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will put terror on the land of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “pour out my fury” represents punishing the people because of his great anger. Alternate translation: “For I will act in great anger against Pelusium” or “Because I am so angry, I will punish Pelusium severely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For I will pour out my fury on Pelusium

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “cut off” represents killing the people. Alternate translation: “kill the very large number of people in Thebes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: cut off the multitude of Thebes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “yoke” here refers to Egypt’s power to oppress people. Alternate translation: “when I stop Egypt from oppressing people” or “when I end Egypt’s power to cruelly control other nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: when I break the yoke of Egypt there

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents Egypt no longer being proud of their strength. The reason that they will not be proud is that they will no longer be strong. Alternate translation: “Egypt will no longer be proud about being strong” or “Egypt will no longer have the strength that they were so proud of” (See:[[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the pride of her strength will be finished

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the dark cloud represents how sad the people of Egypt will feel. Alternate translation: “It will be as if there is a cloud over Egypt” or (2) there will be a cloud of dust over Egypt from everything that is destroyed. Alternate translation: “A cloud of dust will be over Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: There will be a cloud covering her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “covered” possibly refers to putting on clothes for mourning. Alternate translation: “I made the water from the springs mourn for the cedar” or “it was as though the springs that watered it mourned for it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I covered the deep waters over it

contextId.occurrenceNote: God’s punishment of Pharaoh is spoken of as if the king were the river monster caught in a net. Alternate translation: “So I will gather many peoples and throw my net over you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: So I will spread my net over you in the assembly of many peoples

contextId.occurrenceNote: It was common to speak of a person’s life as if it were a lamp that could be put out. Alternate translation: “When I destroy you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: when I extinguish you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of making the stars dark as if he were putting a cover over the sky. Alternate translation: “I will make everything in the sky go dark” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will cover the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: The nation of Egypt, symbolized by its king, is spoken of as if it were a building that was collapsing. Alternate translation: “when nations hear about the way I destroyed you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: when I bring about your collapse among the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idea of falling down (“downfall”) represents dying. Alternate translation: “when I destroy you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: on the day of your downfall

contextId.occurrenceNote: It was normal in biblical language to represent countries and lands as if they were women. Alternate translation: “in it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: in her

contextId.occurrenceNote: It was normal in biblical language to represent countries and lands as if they were women. Alternate translation: “over it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: over her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land of Assyria is represented as a woman. Alternate translation: “The people of Assyria and all its army are there in Sheol” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Assyria is there with all her assembly

contextId.occurrenceNote: Shame is spoken of as if it were an object that one could carry where he goes. Alternate translation: “who feel ashamed” or “who are now disgraced” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: who carry their own shame

contextId.occurrenceNote: Space being made in Sheol for the dead is spoken of as if the dead were given beds to lie on. Alternate translation: “They gave beds to Elam and all its people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They set a bedroll for Elam and all her multitudes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The warriors’ iniquities cover their bodies, although one would expect that their shields would cover them in death. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: their iniquities over their bones

contextId.occurrenceNote: The time during which these warriors were living is spoken of as if it were a place. Alternate translation: “while they were alive” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: in the land of the living

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person no longer behaving in a certain way is spoken of as if he physically turns and goes back on a path. Alternate translation: “he might stop doing bad things, and if he does not stop doing bad things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he might turn back from it, and if he does not turn back from his way

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “on us” is a metaphor that means they feel guilty for their transgressions and sins or (2) “on us” is a metaphor that means they realize that Yahweh is punishing them for their transgressions and sins. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Our transgressions and our sins are on us
