contextId.occurrenceNote: “we are rotting away because of them.” Being destroyed because of sin is spoken of as if the person’s flesh were rotting. Alternate translation: “they are destroying us” or “they are killing us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: we are decaying in them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “way” represents how a person behaves. Alternate translation: “if the wicked person stops doing bad things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: if the wicked repents from his way

contextId.occurrenceNote: Acting or behaving in a certain way is spoken of as if it were walking. Alternate translation: “lives according to the laws that give life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: walks in the statutes that give life

contextId.occurrenceNote: Behaviors or actions is spoken of as if they were a way or road on which a person travels. Alternate translation: “What the Lord does … the things you do that are not fair” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The way of the Lord & your ways that are not fair

contextId.occurrenceNote: No longer doing something is spoken of as if it were physically turning away from something. Alternate translation: “stops doing what is right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: turns away from his righteousness

contextId.occurrenceNote: No longer doing something is spoken of as if it were physically turning away from something. Alternate translation: “stops doing wicked things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: turns away from his wickedness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh giving the land to Abraham is spoken of as if Abraham inherited the land. Alternate translation: “Yahweh gave him the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he inherited the land

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In chapter 34, Yahweh speaks of the people of Israel as if they were a flock of sheep and the leaders of Israel were the shepherds that were supposed to care for the flock but have not. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The leaders of Israel are spoken as if they were shepherds. They were supposed to take care of their people like shepherds take care of their flock. Alternate translation: “the leaders of Israel who are like shepherds” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the shepherds of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The leaders taking care of themselves instead of the people are spoken of as if they were shepherding themselves. AT “are feeding and taking care of themselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: are shepherding themselves

contextId.occurrenceNote: This continues speaking of the leaders of Israel as if they were bad shepherds that kill the best animals in their flock for food and clothing. Alternate translation: “You are like shepherds who eat the fatty portions … dress in wool” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You eat the fatty portions & dress in wool

contextId.occurrenceNote: “on the cloudy and dark day.” Disasters are spoken of as if they were a day of darkness. Alternate translation: “when terrible disasters happened to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: on the day of clouds and darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh bringing his people back from exile to their land so that he can care for them and keep them safe is spoken of as if he were their shepherd who puts his flock in a place where there is plenty of land, food, and water. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will put them in pastures & every settlement in the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The leaders and strong people in Israel are spoken of as if they were fat and strong animals in the flock. The poor and weak people in Israel are spoken of as if they were the thin and weak animals in the flock. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the fat sheep and the thin ones

contextId.occurrenceNote: The descendant of David who will be king over the people of Israel is spoken of as if he would be their shepherd. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will shepherd them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Slavery is spoken of as if it were a yoke that people wear like some animals. Alternate translation: “when I free them from being slaves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: when I break the bars of their yoke

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the people of Israel as if they were a flock of sheep and Yahweh is their shepherd. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For you are my sheep, the flock of my pasture

contextId.occurrenceNote: This metaphor could mean: (1) “you gave them over to their enemies who killed them with swords” or (2) “you killed them with swords.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you poured them out into the hands of the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “cut off” is a metaphor that means to destroy. Alternate translation: “I will destroy anyone who enters it or leaves it” or (2) “cut off” is a metaphor that means to stop someone from doing something. Alternate translation: “I will make it so that people do not travel back and forth through it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: when I cut off from it anyone who passes through and returns again

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Mount Seir taking the land of Israel and using it for themselves is spoken of as if they were wild animals that would devour the mountains of Israel. Alternate translation: “they are here for us to devour” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they have been given over to us to devour

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the land that Yahweh gave to the Israelites as their inheritance. Alternate translation: “As you rejoiced when I made the land of the Israelites desolate” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: As you rejoiced over the inheritance of the people of Israel because of its desolation

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh’s fury as if it were a fire. Yahweh loves Israel very much, so he becomes jealous and angry when other nations mock it. Alternate translation: “because of my intense jealousy” or “because of my very strong anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: in the fire of my fury

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people experiencing shame are spoken of as if they will carry their shame. Alternate translation: “that people will certainly mock the nations that surround you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: that the nations that surround you will certainly carry their own shame

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people living in the mountains and land of Israel permanently is spoke of as if the people would inherit them. Alternate translation: “They will possess you permanently” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They will possess you, and you will be their inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: Not enough food growing in Israel so that people die is spoken of as if the mountains of Israel were devouring the people. Alternate translation: “You cause many people to die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You devour men

contextId.occurrenceNote: Not enough food growing in Israel so that people die is spoken of as if the mountains of Israel were consuming the people. Alternate translation: “you will no longer cause the people to die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you will not consume people any longer

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh punishing people because he is angry is spoken of as if his fury were a liquid that he poured out. Alternate translation: “I did things to them that showed how angry I was” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I poured out my fury against them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people worshiping idols is spoken of as if the idols made the land physically dirty. Alternate translation: “because they defiled the land with their idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for their pollution of it by their idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh forgiving the people and causing them to no longer sin is spoken of as if he would cleanse them with water. The phrase “you will be purified” can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “I will purify you as if I were sprinkling you with pure water, and I will cause you to stop worshiping idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: I will sprinkle pure water on you so you will be purified from all of your impurities, and I will purify you from all of your idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing the people to no longer be stubborn but to love and serve Yahweh is spoken of as if he will take away their old heart and give them a new heart and spirit. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will give you a new heart and a new spirit in your innermost parts, and I will take away the heart of stone from your flesh & or I will give you a heart of flesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Something that is unacceptable to Yahweh is spoken of as if it were physically unclean. Alternate translation: “For I will save you from everything that made me reject you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For I will save you from all of your uncleanness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing a famine in the land is spoken of as if he put famine on the people. Alternate translation: “I will no longer cause there to be a famine” or “I will no longer cause there to be no food” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will no longer put famine upon you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Experiencing shame is spoken of as if the people had to carry the shame. Alternate translation: “the nations will no longer make you feel ashamed because you suffer from famine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you will no longer bear the shame of famine among the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing the people to multiply greatly and quickly is spoken of as if they were a flock of sheep. Sheep multiply very quickly. Alternate translation: “to make them multiply like a flock of sheep” or “to make the people multiply quickly like sheep” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to increase them like a flock of people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the people of Israel as if they were a flock of sheep. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “so will the great number of people be who will be living in the cities that are now ruined but the people will rebuild” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: so will the ruined cities be filled with flocks of people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people being destroyed and removed from their land is spoken of as if they had been cut off like a person would cut off a branch or piece of cloth. Alternate translation: “Our nation is destroyed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: We have been cut off

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh restoring the people and bringing them back to their land is spoken of as if he will bring them back to life again. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will open your graves and lift you out from them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of acting or behaving in a certain way as if it were a person walking. Alternate translation: “will live as I have commanded” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will walk according to my decrees

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hooks in your jaw” represents God’s control over Gog. People put hooks in the mouths of animals so that they could lead the animals wherever they wanted. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: set hooks in your jaw

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mount up” means “rise up” and expresses that his wrath will increase. The words “wrath” and “anger” mean the same thing and emphasize how intense his anger will be. Alternate translation: “my anger will greatly increase” or “I will be very angry with you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: my wrath will mount up in my anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: The intensity of Yahweh’s anger is spoken of as if it were as hot as fire. Alternate translation: “because my anger was intense” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: in the fire of my anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of leading Gog as if Gog was an animal. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will turn you and lead you on

contextId.occurrenceNote: Knocking Gog’s bow and arrows out of his hands is spoken of as if God is destroying Gog’s military power. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will knock your bow out of your left hand and make the arrows fall from your right hand.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The scavengers eating the corpses is spoken of as if Yahweh was giving food to them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will give you to the birds of prey and the wild beasts of the fields for food

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of his glory as if he will place it in the middle of the nations where they can see it. Alternate translation: “I will make the nations see my glory” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will set my glory among the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the people’s disgusting behavior as if they were physically unclean. Here “uncleanness” means basically the same as “sins.” Alternate translation: “their disgusting behavior and their sins” or “their sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: their uncleanness and their sins

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here to give the Spirit abundantly is spoken of as to “pour out” the Spirit. Alternate translation: “when I generously give my Spirit to the house of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: when I pour out my Spirit on the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idols that the people’s kings worshiped are spoken of as if they are corpses because the idols are not alive. Alternate translation: “the lifeless idols that their kings worshiped” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the corpses of their kings

contextId.occurrenceNote: The way a person lives is spoken of as walking on a path. Alternate translation: “stopped worshiping me … stopped doing what I wanted them to do. Instead, they worshiped their idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: went far from me & wandered away from me, going after their idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who causes another person to sin is spoken of as if he were something on a path over which people stumble. Alternate translation: “became people who caused the house of Israel to sin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: became stumbling blocks for sin for the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: “this land which is the firstfruits.” Here “firstfruits” probably means the best things among all the offerings set aside to give to God. This land is spoken of in that way, as land set aside for Yahweh’s use. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: this firstfruits

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hand” is often used to refer to someone’s power or action. A person with his hand on another person has power over that other person. Alternate translation: “Yahweh was controlling him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the hand of Yahweh was upon him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Bible sometimes refers to thunder as “the voice of the Almighty.” Alternate translation: “It sounded like the voice of the Almighty God” or “It sounded like the thunder of the Almighty” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Like the voice of the Almighty

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “voice” is a metonym for the person. Alternate translation: “I heard someone speaking” or “Someone spoke, and I heard his voice” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I heard a voice speaking

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, in this case the Israelites, the descendants of Jacob over many years. Alternate translation: “people group” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: house

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “their faces” are a metonym for the message the people express with their faces. Alternate translation: “lose your desire to serve me because of the way they look at you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: be dismayed by their faces

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, in this case the Israelites, the descendants of Jacob over many years. Alternate translation: “the Israelites” or “the Israelite people group” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “brow” is the forehead or eyebrow and is a metonym for what the person thinks. Alternate translation: “I have made … you strong so you will not stop doing what you are doing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I have made & your brow as hard as their brows

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents a person’s mind. Alternate translation: “remember them and listen carefully” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: take them into your heart and hear them with your ears

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the word “hand” is often used to refer to someone’s power or action. Alternate translation: “the power of Yahweh” or (2) Ezekiel knew that Yahweh was angry with him because he was not obeying Yahweh by speaking to the Israelite exiles. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the hand of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hand” is often used to refer to someone’s power or action. Alternate translation: “the power of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the hand of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “face” is a metonym for attention or gaze, and “set your face” refers to literally staring at something. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: set your face

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “face” is a metonym for attention or gaze. “Set your face” refers to literally staring at something. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Set your face

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “shaking” is a metaphor for being afraid and “trembling” represents fear. Alternate translation: “rationing it while shaking” or “rationing it in fear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: rationing it in trembling

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” is a metonym for enemy soldiers who will attack with their swords, and to “draw out a sword” is to send the soldiers into battle. Alternate translation: “I will cause their enemies to pursue them and attack them with swords” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will draw out a sword to chase after the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “fury” means violent anger, and here it is a metonym for punishment. “I will stop punishing them because I will have punished them fully.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will cause my fury toward them to rest

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “arrows” is a metonym for the sharp pains that people feel when they have had no food for a long time. Alternate translation: “will make you feel the pain of intense hunger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: will send out harsh arrows of famine against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “face” is a metonym for attention or gaze. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: set your face

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” is a metonym for soldiers who kill people using swords. Alternate translation: “I am bringing soldiers to come and kill you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I am bringing a sword against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” is a metonym for soldiers who kill people using swords. Alternate translation: “some whom the soldiers do not kill” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: some who escape the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “land” is a metonym for the people who live on the land. Alternate translation: “to the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to the land of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “mountains” is a metonym for the people who live on the mountains. Alternate translation: “the people on the mountains will not have any more joy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the mountains will no longer be joyful

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hand” is used to refer to control. “I will give those idols into the control of people they do not know” or “I will give those idols to people they do not know” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will give those things into the hand of strangers

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “everywhere in the country God is judging people because they violently killed others” or (2) “the courts everywhere in the country are murdering people.” The word “blood” here represents murder and death. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the land is filled with the judgment of blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “city” is a metonym for the people in the city. Alternate translation: “attacked the people in the city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: attacked the city

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym “hands” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “put you into the power of foreigners” or “enable foreigners to capture you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: put you into the hands of foreigners

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” is a metonym for soldiers who kill people using swords. Alternate translation: “They will kill you with their swords” or “You will die in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: You will fall by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym “heart” represents the will and emotions. Yahweh speaks of causing all of the people to share the same new emotions as if he were giving them one heart. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will give them one heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym “spirit” represents the thoughts and disposition. Yahweh speaks of causing the people to think new thoughts as if he were giving them a new spirit. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will put a new spirit within them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym “conduct” represents the consequences of their actions. The idiom “bring … on their own heads” means they will experience these consequences. Alternate translation: “I will cause them to suffer the consequences of their actions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will bring their conduct on their own heads

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” is a metonym for enemy armies who will attack with their swords. Alternate translation: “I will send armies to pursue them with swords” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will send out a sword after them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” is a metonym for soldiers who kill people using swords. You may need to make explicit that they will not die from famine or plague. Alternate translation: “I will keep … from dying in battle, from starving to death, and from dying of disease” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will spare & from the sword, famine, and plague

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” represents Yahweh’s power. That his hand will be against them is a metaphor that means that he will punish them with his power. Alternate translation: “I will punish the prophets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: My hand will be against the prophets

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “face” is a metonym for attention or gaze, and “set your face” represents staring. Alternate translation: “stare at” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: set your face against

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “rescue my people from your power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: rescue my people from your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” represents power or control. Yahweh speaks of the people being in the control of these women as if the women had trapped them with their hands. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “you will no longer trap them like prey in your hands” or “you will no longer control them with your power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they will no longer be trapped in your hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hearts” represents the minds and affections of the people. Yahweh speaks of causing them to be devoted to him once again as if he were to capture their hearts. Alternate translation: “I will cause the people of Israel to be devoted to me again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I may take back the house of Israel in their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hearts” represents the minds and affections of the people. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “who have all left me to worship their idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: their hearts that have been driven far from me through their idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “face” is a metonym for attention or gaze, and “set my face” refers to staring. Alternate translation: “stare” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: set my face

contextId.occurrenceNote: God’s “hand” refers to what he does. Alternate translation: “I will work against him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will reach out with my hand against him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “iniquity” represents the guilt that people incur for committing iniquity. Yahweh speaks of people suffering the consequences of their iniquity as if they were carrying the iniquity. Alternate translation: “They will suffer the consequences of their own iniquity” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They will carry their own iniquity

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “land” represents the people who live in the land. Alternate translation: “when the people who live in a land sin against me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: when a land sins against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “sword” represents the soldiers of an enemy army who attack with swords. Alternate translation: “Army, go through the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Sword, go through the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “face” is a metonym for attention or gaze, and “set my face” refers to staring. Alternate translation: “stare” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: set my face

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power. Alternate translation: “I will use my power to strike you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will strike you with my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” represents the will and emotions. Yahweh speaks of her inability to control her desires as if her heart were sick. Alternate translation: “How weak-willed are you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: How sick is your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase represents murder in any form. Alternate translation: “murder” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the shedding of blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bloodshed” represents murder in any form. This could mean: (1) Yahweh speaks of punishing her for murder as if he were bringing bloodshed upon her. Alternate translation: “In my anger and passion, I will punish you for committing murder” or (2) Yahweh speaks of putting her to death as if he were bringing bloodshed upon her. Alternate translation: “In my anger and passion, I will shed your blood” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will bring on you the bloodshed of my anger and passion

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hands” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “I will place you in their control” or “I will allow them to have power over you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will give you into their hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “fury” and “anger” refer to the punishment that Yahweh inflicts because he is angry. The two phrases mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: “I will stop punishing you because I will no longer be angry with you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: I will calm my fury against you; my anger will leave you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “land” represents the kingdom of Judah and the people in it. Alternate translation: “the kingdom will continue to exist” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the land will survive

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “fall” is a euphemism for “die.” Here the word “sword” is a metonym for soldiers who kill people with swords. Alternate translation: “Soldiers will kill all his refugees … armies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: All of his refugees & armies will fall by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: land of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase represents murder in any form. Alternate translation: “who murders” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: who sheds blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “blood” represents death. For blood to be on a person is an idiom that means the person is responsible for that death. Alternate translation: “he will be responsible for his own death” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: his blood will be on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the stumbling blocks cause the person to commit more iniquity. Alternate translation: “stumbling blocks that cause you to commit more iniquity” or (2) The word “iniquity” is a metonym for the punishment that a person receives for his iniquity. Alternate translation: “stumbling blocks that lead to your punishment” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: stumbling blocks of iniquity against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” represents the will and emotions and the word “spirit” represents the thoughts and disposition. Yahweh speaks of the people having new emotions and thoughts as if they were making a new heart and spirit for themselves. Alternate translation: “get for yourselves new emotions and a new way of thinking” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: make for yourselves a new heart and a new spirit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are that **blood** represents (1) the violence of the kings of Judah who had murdered people. Alternate translation: “a vine planted by means of violence” or (2) The plentiful wine of Judah which had become a symbol of prosperity. Alternate translation: “a vine planted in your prosperity” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: a vine planted in your blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “name” represents Yahweh’s reputation. Alternate translation: “for the sake of my reputation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: for my name’s sake

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “nations” is a metonym for the people who live in the nations. Alternate translation: “the people who live in other nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” represents the person’s thoughts and emotions. Yahweh speaks of being dedicated to idols as if a person’s heart walked after them. Alternate translation: “they were dedicated to worshiping their idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: their hearts walked after their idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “name” represents Yahweh’s reputation. Alternate translation: “for the sake of my reputation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: for my name’s sake

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “nations” refer to the people who live in those places. The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: “in the thoughts of the people in other nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: in the eyes of the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “hand” and “arm” both represent power. Alternate translation: “with very great power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: with a mighty hand, a raised arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “name” represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “dishonor me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: profane my holy name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “name” represents Yahweh’s reputation. Alternate translation: “because of my reputation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: because of my name’s sake

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “face” is a metonym for attention or gaze, and “set your face” represents staring. Alternate translation: “stare” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: set your face

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “flesh” represents all humans. The idiom to “see” means to understand. Alternate translation: “all people will understand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: all flesh will see

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “flesh” is a metonym for “people.” Alternate translation: “all people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: all flesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh refers to the king of Judah as his son. The king’s scepter represents his rule as king. It is important to maintain the image of the king’s scepter here, as the words “every such rod” refer to the scepter. Alternate translation: “in the king’s scepter” or “in the power that the king’s scepter represents” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in my son’s scepter

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the king of Judah is represented by his scepter. Alternate translation: “the king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the scepter

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “fallen” refers to the people killed in battle. This means there will be a greater number of people killed. Alternate translation: “to kill many people among them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to multiply their fallen

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” is a metonym for soldiers who kill people using swords. Alternate translation: “the soldiers of the king of Babylon” or “the Babylonian army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the sword of the king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means the he will hold one of the articles of his divination that was read as an omen against Jerusalem in his right hand. Alternate translation: “In his right hand will be an article of divination with an omen against Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: In his right hand will be an omen about Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the crown represents the position of king. The kingship will not be restored until the Messiah comes. Alternate translation: “There will no longer be a king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: It will not be restored

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “hand” of the men refers to their control. Alternate translation: “the control of cruel men” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the hand of cruel men

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “blood” is a metonym for murder. Alternate translation: “the city where many people murder their neighbors” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the city of blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “city” represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “The people who live in this city pour … its midst” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: This is a city that pours & her midst

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “nations” refer to the people who live in those places. Alternate translation: “the people in other nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “land” represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “for the people so that I would not destroy them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: for the land so I would not destroy it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hand” refers to power or control. The two phrases have the same meaning and the second phrase explains that “her lovers” were “the Assyrians.” Alternate translation: “I gave her over to her lovers, the Assyrians” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: I gave her into the hand of her lovers, into the hand of the Assyrians

contextId.occurrenceNote: These defensive items are used to refer to various types of soldiers. Alternate translation: “Soldiers will attack you on all sides carrying large shields, small shields, and wearing helmets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: They will set large shields, small shields, and helmets against you all around

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Egypt” represents the shameful things that she did in Egypt. Alternate translation: “you will think about the things you did in Egypt no longer” or “you will not think about what you did in Egypt any more” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you will think of Egypt no longer

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” refers to control. Alternate translation: “into the control” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: into the hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh speaks of punishment as if it were a cup of wine the woman drank. Alternate translation: “You will drink the same cup of punishment as your sister” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: You will drink your sister’s cup

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “cup” represents what is in the cup. Alternate translation: “from your sister’s cup that is” or “all that is in your sister’s cup, and her cup is” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: your sister’s cup that is

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sound of the crowd is used to refer to the crowd of people. Alternate translation: “So there was a noisy crowd around her” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: So the sound of a noisy crowd was around her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The army of Babylon is referred to by its leader. Alternate translation: “the army of the king of Babylon has besieged” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the king of Babylon has besieged

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “blood” is a reference to “murder.” Alternate translation: “the city of murderers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the city of blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “blood” is a reference to “murder.” Alternate translation: “the city of murderers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the city of blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh punishing the people in his anger as if it were his “fury” that were punishing them. Alternate translation: “until I am finished punishing you and am no longer furious with you” or “until I have punished you and I am longer angry with you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: until I have satisfied my fury upon you.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes the temple as the building that the people are proud of. This speaks of it as being their “pride” instead of the source of their pride. Alternate translation: “the building that you are proud of” or “the source of your strong pride” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the pride of your power

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to their enemies by their swords. Alternate translation: “your sons and daughters … will be killed in war” or “your enemies will kill your sons and your daughters … with their swords” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: your sons and your daughters & will fall by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the phrase “the people of Ammon” refers to the land that belonged to the people of Ammon. Also, the understood information at the beginning of this phrase may be supplied. Alternate translation: “I will make the rest of the land of Ammon a field for flocks” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the people of Ammon a field for flocks

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the phrase “the land of Israel” represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “all of the hatred you feel towards the people who live in Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: all the contempt within you against the land of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “you” refers to the people of Ammon but is also a metonym for their land and their possessions. Alternate translation: “I will allow enemies to defeat you and take you, your land, and your possessions as plunder” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: give you as plunder to the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: These places refer to the people who live in them. Alternate translation: “the people of Moab and Seir” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Moab and Seir

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Edom” refers to the people who live there. Alternate translation: “The people of Edom have taken” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Edom has taken

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “fall” represents being killed and the word “sword” refers to their enemies who will kill them in battle. Alternate translation: “Their enemies will kill them with their swords” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: They will fall by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “hand” of Israel is a metonym for Israel’s army. Yahweh speaks of taking revenge on the people of Edom as if his vengeance were like a sheet that he covered them with. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **vengeance**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “to punish.” Alternate translation: “I will use my people Israel to punish the people of Edom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will lay my vengeance upon Edom by the hand of my people Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Judah” refers to the people who live there. Alternate translation: “to destroy the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to destroy Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh’s power is represented by his “hand.” Alternate translation: “I will turn my powerful hand against the Philistines” or “I will turn my great power against the Philistines” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will reach out with my hand against the Philistines

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the city names “Tyre” and “Jerusalem” represent the people of those cities. Alternate translation: “the people of Tyre have said against the people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Tyre has said against Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here to be “filled up” represents being prosperous. Alternate translation: “I will become prosperous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will be filled up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “nations” refers to their armies. Alternate translation: “I will gather armies from many nations that will beat against you like the waves in the raging sea” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: I will raise up many nations against you like the sea raises its waves

contextId.occurrenceNote: Part of Tyre was an island. This expression is a metonym for the results of Tyre’s destruction. Alternate translation: “an empty island used for drying fishing nets” or “a deserted island where people dry out their fishing nets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: a place for nets to dry out in the midst of the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Plunder” means things that people steal or take by force. Here Tyre becoming plunder represents its wealth being carried off by other nations. Alternate translation: “the armies of the nations will take away every valuable thing from Tyre” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: she will become plunder for the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “Her daughters” were the young women of Tyre who were working in the fields or (2) “Her daughters” is a metonym for nearby towns and villages on the mainland that supported the main city of Tyre. Alternate translation: “Her daughter communities who are on the mainland” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Her daughters who are in the fields

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “He” refers to Nebuchadnezzar and is a metonym for his army. Alternate translation: “His army will kill” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He will kill

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

The words “he” and “his” in these verses refer to Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, and represent the soldiers in Nebuchadnezzar’s army doing these actions. The word “your” refers to the city of Tyre. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Although the battering rams and tools are spoken of as acting against the walls and towers of Tyre, they would have been used by the soldiers in Nebuchadnezzar’s army against the walls and towers. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He will place his battering rams to hit against your walls, and his tools will tear down your towers

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the islands” represents the people living on the islands. Alternate translation: “Will not the people of the islands quake with fear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Will not the islands quake

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the coasts” represents the people living there. Alternate translation: “Now the people of the coastlands tremble” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Now the coasts tremble

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the islands in the sea” represents the people living there. Alternate translation: “The people of the islands are terrified” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The islands in the sea are terrified

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the grave. Because the grave was thought to be the entrance to the world of the dead, the pit also represents that world. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the pit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “Tyre” represents the people living in Tyre. Alternate translation: “say to the people of Tyre” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: say to Tyre

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “Tyre” represents the people living in Tyre. Alternate translation: “People of Tyre, you have said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Tyre, you have said

contextId.occurrenceNote: Having things in the hands here is probably a metaphor for carrying those things or having them in their possession. Alternate translation: “You owned things that you sold to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Merchandise was in your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Aram” refers to the people of Aram. Alternate translation: “The people of Aram were dealers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Aram was a dealer

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Judah and the land of Israel” refers to the people of those places. Alternate translation: “The people of Judah and Israel were trading with you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Judah and the land of Israel were trading with you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the people of Dan and Javan. Alternate translation: “The people of Dan and Javan” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Dan and Javan

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the people of Dedan. Alternate translation: “The people of Dedan were” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Dedan was

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the people of Arabia. Alternate translation: “The people of Arabia” or “The Arabians” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Arabia

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people from these places. Alternate translation: “The people of Haran, Kanneh, and Eden were traders with you, along with the people of Sheba, Ashur, and Kilmad” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Haran, Kanneh, and Eden were traders with you, along with Sheba, Ashur, and Kilmad

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Cities at the sea” represents the people in those cities. Alternate translation: “The people of the cities by the sea will tremble” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Cities at the sea will tremble

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “faces” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “They appear to be trembling” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Their faces trembled

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents the will or thoughts of the ruler of Tyre. Alternate translation: “You are arrogant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Your heart is arrogant

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents the mind or thinking. A god thinks of himself as better than people. Alternate translation: “you think that you have the mind of a god” or “you have allowed yourself to think that you are better than other people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: you make your heart like the heart of a god

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents the will or thoughts of the ruler of Tyre. Alternate translation: “you are arrogant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: your heart is arrogant

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the pit” refers to the grave or to hell. Alternate translation: “down to the grave” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: down to the pit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” is a metonym for the actions of the foreigners’ army. Alternate translation: “by an army of foreigners” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: by the hand of foreigners

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” is a metonym for an attacking enemy army. Alternate translation: “When enemy armies attack you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: When the sword comes against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jacob” represents the descendants of Jacob. Alternate translation: “the descendants of my servant Jacob” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: my servant Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” is a metonym for battle, and “bring a sword against you” is a metaphor for causing an enemy army to come fight against Egypt. Alternate translation: “I will cause your enemies to come fight against you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will bring a sword against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” refers to Pharaoh and represents Egypt, the country he rules over. Alternate translation: “your country will become a wasteland” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you will become a wasteland

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Egypt” represents the people of Egypt, and “scatter” represents causing them to move to other places. Alternate translation: “I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations” or “I will make the people of Egypt go and live among the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will scatter Egypt among the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Egypt” is a metonym for the people of Egypt, and “gather” is a metaphor for causing them to return to Egypt. Alternate translation: “I will cause the people of Egypt to return to Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will gather Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “the people of Israel” or “the nation of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “turn … for help” is a metonym for “ask … for help.” Alternate translation: “whenever they asked Egypt to help them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: when they turned to Egypt for help

contextId.occurrenceNote: An animal horn represents the animal’s strength, so horn is a metonym for strength. God speaks of making Israel strong as if Israel were an animal, and he were to cause its horn to grow. Alternate translation: “I will make the people of Israel strong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make a horn sprout up for the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. Here it refers to the people of Israel, the descendants of Jacob whom God called Israel. Alternate translation: “the people of Israel” or “the nation of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” here represents war or an army that attacks. Alternate translation: “There will be war against Egypt” or “An enemy army will attack Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Then a sword will come against Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: These names refer to the people of these countries. Alternate translation: “The people of Cush and Put, Libya, and all Arabia, and Lydia” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Cush and Put, Lydia and all Arabia, and Libya

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the sword represents battle. Alternate translation: “will all die in battle” or “will all die in the war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: will all fall by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “set fire in Egypt” represents sending an army to attack Egypt and set fires. Alternate translation: “when I send an army to burn Egypt with fire” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: when I set fire in Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “draw out their swords” represents fighting with their swords. Alternate translation: “they will use their swords and fight against Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: they will draw out their swords against Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Pelusium” is a metonym for the people of the city near Pelusium, and “be in great agony” can be translated with the verb “suffer.” Alternate translation: “The people of Pelusium will suffer terribly” or “The people of Pelusium will feel terrible pain” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Pelusium will be in great agony

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “face enemies” represents seeing or having enemies. The name of the city is a metonym for the people who live in the city. Alternate translation: “The people of Memphis will have enemies every day” or “Enemies will fight against the people of Memphis every day” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Memphis will face enemies every day

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” is used here to refer to a battle or war. Alternate translation: “will die in battle” or “will die in the war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: will fall by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “cities” represents the people of the cities. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **captivity**, you can express the same idea the more concrete noun “captive” or the verb “capture” Alternate translation: “the people of their cities will become captives” or “their enemies will capture their people and take them away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: their cities will go into captivity

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “arms” are a metonym for the army. Alternate translation: “I will make the army of the king of Babylon strong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: For I will strengthen the arms of the king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Pharaoh’s arms” is a metonym for his army, and “will fall” represents being weak. Alternate translation: “but Pharaoh’s army will be unable to defeat enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: while Pharaoh’s arms will fall

contextId.occurrenceNote: “All of the great nations lived in the shade of that tree.” Here “nations” represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “The people from all the nations lived in the shade of that tree” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: All of the many nations lived under its shade

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hand” represents control. Alternate translation: “I put it in the power of the strongest nation” or “I gave the strongest nation power over it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I have given it into the hand of a mighty one of the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: “These trees of Lebanon were its strong arm.” The phrase “strong arm” represents “power.” Alternate translation: “These trees of Lebanon were the power of the cedar” or “These trees strengthened the cedar” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: These were its strong arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents the people’s emotions. Alternate translation: “I will make the hearts of many peoples afraid” or “I will cause many people to be terrified” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will terrify the heart of many peoples

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here swinging a sword represents using the sword. Alternate translation: “when I use my sword” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: when I swing my sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents an army. Alternate translation: “The army of the king of Babylon will attack you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The sword of the king of Babylon will come against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hoof is a synecdoche for cattle. Alternate translation: “cattle stir them with their hooves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the hooves of cattle stir them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the idea of attacking represents destroying. Alternate translation: “when I destroy all who live in her” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: when I attack all the inhabitants in her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” here is a metonym for war that people fight with swords. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “War has begun” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The sword has been drawn!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” is a metonym for soldiers who use swords to kill people. This can be put in active form. Alternate translation: “Soldiers used swords to kill them all” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: all of them were killed by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents the people who were alive. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the land of the living

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Elam” refers to the people of that country. Alternate translation: “The people of Elam are also there in Sheol” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Elam is there

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the sword” is a metonym for soldiers who use swords to kill people. Alternate translation: “in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “pierced” here is a metonym for “killed.” This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “their enemies have killed them with swords because” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: pierced by the sword, because

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the sword” represents warfare. Alternate translation: “killed in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: killed by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents being in warfare. Alternate translation: “in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Edom” represents all the people of Edom. Alternate translation: “the people of Edom are in Sheol with their kings and all their leaders” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Edom is there with her kings and all her leaders

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents being in warfare. Alternate translation: “in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” refers to an enemy army that attacks. Also, “land” refers to the people who live there. Alternate translation: “an army to attack the people of any land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: a sword against any land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents an enemy army. Alternate translation: “He looks for an enemy army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He looks for the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “blood” represents death. The phrase “on his own head” is an idiom that means the person will be held responsible. Alternate translation: “it is their own fault if they die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: each one’s blood is on his own head

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” refers to an enemy army. Alternate translation: “the enemy army as it is coming” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the sword as it is coming

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents an enemy army. Alternate translation: “the enemy army comes and kills anyone” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the sword comes and takes anyone’s life

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “blood” represents a person’s death. The phrase “I will require his blood from” is an idiom that means to consider someone responsible. Alternate translation: “I will consider that person’s death to be the fault of the watchman” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will require his blood from the watchman

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents people. Alternate translation: “the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mouth” represents what Yahweh says. Alternate translation: “you will hear the message that I speak and you will warn them on my behalf” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you will hear the words from my mouth and warn them on my behalf

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “blood” represents a person’s death. The phrase “require … from your hand” is an idiom that means to consider someone responsible. Alternate translation: “I will consider you responsible for his death” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will require his blood from your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents people. Alternate translation: “the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents people. Alternate translation: “people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “blood” represents a person’s life. To pour out blood is an idiom that means to murder. Alternate translation: “you murder people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: you pour out people’s blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “swords” represent doing violent things. Alternate translation: “You have committed violent acts with your swords to get what you want” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: You have depended on your swords

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “it” refers to the land, which refers to the people of the land. Alternate translation: “the people of the land will not be proud anymore that they are strong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the pride of its might will end

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mouths” represent speaking. This could mean: (1) Alternate translation: “They speak about loving me, but their hearts are going after unjust profit” or (2) Alternate translation: “They speak about the things they lust after, and their hearts are going after unjust profit” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Right words are in their mouths, but their hearts are going after unjust profit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hearts” represents desire. Alternate translation: “in their hearts they want to get their unjust profit” or “they desire to get things in ways that are not just” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: their hearts are going after unjust profit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” refers to Ezekiel, and here he represents the message he speaks. This compares Ezekiel’s message to a lovely song, which means the people enjoy listening to him, but they do not think his message is important enough to obey. Alternate translation: “they think that your words are like a lovely song” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: you are like a lovely song to them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mouths” represent eating. Alternate translation: “so they cannot eat them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: from their mouths

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “David” refers to a descendant of David. Alternate translation: “a descendant of my servant David” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: my servant David

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “from the control of those who made them slaves” or “from those who made them slaves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: from the hand of those who enslaved them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “nations” represents the people of the nations. Alternate translation: “The people of the nations will no longer steal from them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: They will no longer be plunder for the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “nations” represents the people of the nations. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **scorn**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “they will no longer hear the people of the nations insult them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: they will not bear the scorn of the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power. Alternate translation: “I will use my power to strike you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will strike you with my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bloodshed” is a metonym for killing. Alternate translation: “I will make it easy for your enemies to kill many of you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will prepare you for bloodshed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bloodshed” is a metonym for killing. Alternate translation: “Since you did not hate it when enemies brutally killed the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Since you did not hate bloodshed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “earth” represents the people of the earth. The word “entire” is a generalization that refers only to people near Mount Seir. Alternate translation: “people who know that I have destroyed you rejoice” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the entire earth rejoices

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” and “spirit” represent a person’s inner being. The ideas of having joy and disdain can be expressed with the verbs “rejoiced” and “despised.” Alternate translation: “who despised the people of Israel and rejoiced while they took my land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: had both joy in their heart and disdain in their spirit, as they seized my land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents people. Alternate translation: “all of the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: even the whole house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents people. Alternate translation: “the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” represents Yahweh and his reputation. Alternate translation: “they mocked me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: they profaned my holy name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” represents Yahweh and his reputation. Alternate translation: “When the house of Israel went among the nations, they caused me disgrace, but I wanted people to know that I am holy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: But I had compassion for my holy name that the house of Israel had defiled among the nations, when they went there

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents people. Alternate translation: “the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents people. Alternate translation: “the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” represents Yahweh and his reputation. Alternate translation: “but so that the people of the nations, who mock me because of you, will know that I am holy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: but for my holy name, which you have profaned among the nations everywhere you have gone

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents people. Alternate translation: “people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes represent sight. Alternate translation: “to those who pass by and see it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: before the eyes of all who pass by

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents people. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The people of Israel will ask me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: I will be asked by the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the stick of Joseph.” This represents the kingdom of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the branch of Joseph

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hand” refers to power. Alternate translation: “that is in the power of Ephraim” or “that the tribe of Ephraim rules over” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: that is in the hand of Ephraim

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the stick of Judah.” This represents the kingdom of Judah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the branch of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “face” is a metonym for attention or gaze, and “set your face” represents staring. Alternate translation: “stare” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: set your face

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “sword” represents war. Alternate translation: “recovered from war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: recovered from the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” refers to his thinking. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “you will think of plans” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: plans will form in your heart
