contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to Gog’s military power. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: bring my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “ruins” refers to the people who live in the destroyed cities. Alternate translation: “against the people who live in the ruins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: against the ruins

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to the fact that these prophets wrote down Yahweh’s message. Alternate translation: “by means of my servants” or “through my servants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: by the hand of my servants

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” here is a metonym for soldiers who use swords to kill people. Alternate translation: “I will cause soldiers to attack him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will summon a sword against him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” is a metonym for the person who uses the sword to fight. Alternate translation: “all of his soldiers will fight each other” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: each man’s sword will be against his brother

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “blood” is a metonym for injury and death. Alternate translation: “I will judge him by causing him to be sick and by sending soldiers to kill him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will judge him by plague and blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “eyes” refers to sight, which is a metonym for understanding. Alternate translation: “I will cause many nations to understand who I am” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make myself known in the eyes of the many nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) Yahweh will send literal fire down on Gog and his army or (2) “fire” is a metonym for the destruction that it causes. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will send out fire on Magog

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym “my holy name” refers to Yahweh’s character. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will make my people, Israel, know that I am holy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make my holy name known in the midst of my people Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The metonym “chariot” refers to the men in the chariots. Alternate translation: “chariot driver” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: chariot

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym “hand” refers to Yahweh’s power that he uses to bring punishment. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym “hand” refers to power. Alternate translation: “gave their enemies power over them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: gave them into the hand of their adversaries

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sight” is a metonym for understanding. Alternate translation: “many nations will understand that I am holy because of what I did for the house of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will show myself to be holy in the sight of many nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The person is a metonym for his descendants. Alternate translation: “the descendants of Joseph will receive two areas of land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Joseph will have two portions

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both “The time” and “the day” refer to the time when God will punish the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “Israel’s punishment will happen very soon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: The time is coming; the day has come close

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The repetition emphasizes the surety of Yahweh’s promise to bring the exiles back to the land of Israel. Alternate translation: “I will bring you back from all of the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: I will gather you from the peoples, and assemble you from the lands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Each of these phrases have similar meanings and describes the people as obeying what Yahweh has commanded them to do. They are repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: they will walk in my statutes, they will carry out my decrees and do them

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: “when I cause them to separate from each other and live in different nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: when I scatter them among the nations and disperse them throughout the lands

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases are both ways the people of Israel are saying Ezekiel’s warnings will not happen in their lifetime but will happen far in the future. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: The vision that he sees is for many days from now, and he prophesies of far off times

contextId.occurrenceNote: Barley is a grain used to make bread and the word “crumb” is a small amount of bread. Both phrases are small amounts of food and are used to emphasize how small the payment was to the prophetesses. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: handfuls of barley and crumbs of bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases refer to talking about what will happen in the future. Alternate translation: “continue to make false predictions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: have false visions or continue to make predictions

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases are ways to tell the people of Israel to stop worshiping idols. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Repent and turn away from your idols! Turn back your faces from all your abominations

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases repeat the thought of a man dying because of his sin to express that it was his fault and the fault of no one else. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: dies because of them & die in the iniquity that he has done

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks Ezekiel the same question twice in order to secure Ezekiel’s commitment to pronounce the judgement. Alternate translation: “Are you ready to pronounce judgment on them, son of man?” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Will you judge them? Will you judge, son of man?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases refer to the place where the two roads meet. Alternate translation: “at the crossroads” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: at the crossroads, at the junction

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the violence that the princes practice. Alternate translation: “They murder people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: They pour out blood and destroy life

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase means basically the same thing as the previous phrase and emphasizes the immoral behavior of the two young women. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “there men fondled their virgin nipples” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: their virgin nipples were fondled there

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases refer to a person who is laughed at and criticized because of their foolish behavior. Derision is mocking or ridiculing something or someone. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: a laughingstock & a subject for derision

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Ezekiel is not to cry about his wife dying. Alternate translation: “you must not mourn nor weep” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: you must not mourn nor weep, and your tears must not flow

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh will completely destroy the people of Ammon so that they are no longer a nation. Alternate translation: “I will completely destroy you so that you are no longer a nation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: I will cut you off from the peoples & make you perish from among the countries

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases “plunder your riches” and “loot your merchandise” mean about the same thing and are repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: They will plunder your riches and loot your merchandise

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines are similar in meaning and emphasize the response of the surrounding people to the destruction of Tyre. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Now the coasts tremble on the day of your downfall & he islands in the sea are terrified, because you are no longer in your place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jerusalem is referred to as “her” and “she.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: I have placed her

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sickness and violent death are spoken of as if they were soldiers going through the city killing everyone they could. Alternate translation: “Many people will die of disease, and many others will die in war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Plague and blood will pass through you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “end” is spoken of as if it were a robber attacking the people. Alternate translation: “your life is finished” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: the end is upon you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The judgment that is coming is treated as if it were an enemy waking up from sleep. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: The end has woken up against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Disaster is spoken of as if it could move by itself. Alternate translation: “One disaster after another will happen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Disaster upon disaster will come

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the vine as if it were able to behave like a person and intentionally turned its roots toward the other eagle to receive nourishment from it. Alternate translation: “The roots of the vine grew toward the eagle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: This vine turned its roots toward the eagle

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of trees as if they are people who can know about him. The trees represent the nations and the people who live in them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Then all the trees of the field will know that I am Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh not holding back his sword from attacking people as if his sword were a person that was no longer holding itself back from attacking. Alternate translation: “and I will not put it back in its sheath again” or “I will not hold back from attacking people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: It will no longer hold back

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the “news” as if it were a person that was soon coming to them. Alternate translation: “the news that they will soon hear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: the news that is coming

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “sword” is personified as coming to attack the people. This speaks of the king not being able to resist the “sword”, as if the “sword” were hating the king’s scepter. Alternate translation: “the sword will overpower his scepter like that of any other ruler” or “for the king will not be able to resist when the sword is brought against him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: The coming sword hates every such rod

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh’s sword attacking his people as if the sword itself were the attacker. Alternate translation: “I will use my sword to kill my people! I will bring it against all” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: that sword has come against my people! It is against all

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the survivors being burned by fire as if the fire were an animal attacking and eating them. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “your survivors will be burned by fire” or “fire will burn your survivors” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: your survivors will be devoured by fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: This personifies Jerusalem as a person who murdered the people and chose where to put their blood. Alternate translation: “They were murdered on the smooth rocks; not on the dirt where the dust would hide their blood” or “Their blood fell on the smooth rocks; it did not fall on the ground where the dust would cover it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: She has set it on the smooth rock; she has not poured it out on the ground to cover it with dust

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the city of Moab is spoken of with the masculine pronoun “his.” Alternate translation: “starting at its cities” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: starting at his cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: The city of Tyre is spoken of here as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: “Tyre will become” or “It will become” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: She will become

contextId.occurrenceNote: The destruction of Tyre is spoken of as if it was a person who had died. Alternate translation: “you have departed” or “you exist no more” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: you are no longer in your place

contextId.occurrenceNote: What Yahweh would do to Tyre is compared to people going to the grave and cities falling into ruin. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: then I will bring you down to the people of ancient times, like the others who have gone down into the pit; for I will make you live in the lowest realms of the earth as in ruins of ancient times

contextId.occurrenceNote: “I will put Egypt into the power of desolation and waste.” Desolation and waste are spoken of as if they were people who could be given power over Egypt. Alternate translation: “I will cause Egypt to become a desolate waste” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: I will give the land of Egypt over to desolation and waste

contextId.occurrenceNote: The day is spoken of as if it were able to keep its own light from shining. Alternate translation: “the day will be dark” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: the day will hold back its light

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the mountain of Seir.” Yahweh tells Ezekiel to speak to Mount Seir as if it could hear him. The message is for all of the people of Edom. Alternate translation: “Mount Seir and prophesy against it because of what the people of Edom have done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Mount Seir and prophesy against it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh tells Ezekiel to speak to Mount Seir as if it could hear him. The message is for all of the people of Edom. Alternate translation: “Listen, Mount Seir, I will strike you with my hand and make you a desolation and a waste because of what your people did” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Behold! I am against you, Mount Seir, and I will strike you with my hand and make you a desolation and a waste

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bloodshed” is a metonym for killing. Yahweh speaks of bloodshed as if it were a person who could chase them. Alternate translation: “your enemies will chase you down and kill you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: bloodshed will pursue you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “You” refers to the mountain of Seir. Ezekiel is to speak to the mountain as if it can hear him. The message is for the people of Edom. Alternate translation: “Your people said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: You have said

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” refers to Mount Seir, but the message is for the people of Edom. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **desolation**, you can express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “Because of what your people did I will make you desolate” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make you a desolation

contextId.occurrenceNote: God wants Ezekiel to speak to the mountains as if they were people. The message is for the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: prophesy to the mountains of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the mountains as if they were able to hear when people insult them. Alternate translation: “I will no longer allow the other nations to insult you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Nor will I allow you to hear the insults of the nations any longer

contextId.occurrenceNote: Experiencing shame is spoken of as if the mountains could bear shame. Alternate translation: “the peoples will no longer cause you to feel ashamed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you will no longer have to bear the shame of the peoples

contextId.occurrenceNote: “I will call the grain to come.” This phrase presents the grain as a servant of Yahweh. Alternate translation: “I will cause there to be grain in the land of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: I will summon the grain

contextId.occurrenceNote: God uses this question to bring Ezekiel’s attention to what the people were doing. Alternate translation: “I want you to understand why I hate what the people here are doing.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: do you see what they are doing?

contextId.occurrenceNote: God is commanding Ezekiel to look at what the elders are doing. Alternate translation: “look at what the elders of the house of Israel are doing in the dark.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: do you see what the elders of the house of Israel are doing in the dark?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is commanding Ezekiel to think about what he has just seen. Alternate translation: “Think about this … man.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Do you see this & man?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is commanding Ezekiel to think about what he has just seen. Alternate translation: “Think about this … man.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Do you see this & man?

contextId.occurrenceNote: God uses this question to show that he is right to be angry at the people of Judah. Alternate translation: “I am right to be angry at the house of Judah because of these abominations that they are doing here.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is it a little thing for the house of Judah to do these abominations that they are doing here?

contextId.occurrenceNote: God asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel of something he already knew—that the people had asked him this question. Alternate translation: “Son of man, the house of Israel, that rebellious house, is asking, ‘What are you doing?’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Son of man, is the house of Israel, that rebellious house, not asking, ‘What are you doing?’

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel something he already knows. The question is a mild rebuke for the people who use the proverb. Alternate translation: “the people in the land of Israel have this proverb that says, ‘The days are prolonged, and every vision fails.’ (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: what is this proverb that you have in the land of Israel that says, ‘The days are prolonged, and every vision fails’?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to rebuke the false prophets. Alternate translation: “You have had false visions … because I myself have not spoken.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Have you not had false visions & when I myself have not spoken?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that others will ask the prophets what happened to their whitewash. Alternate translation: “Others will certainly say to you, ‘Where is the whitewash that you put on it?’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Have others not said to you, “Where is the whitewash that you put on it?”

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) that this is an honest question for which the people expect and answer or (2) this is a rhetorical question that the people ask out of sarcasm. Alternate translation: “The whitewash that you put on it did no good.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Where is the whitewash that you put on it?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this as a leading question to rebuke the women who do these things. The implicit answer is, “no.” Alternate translation: “Do not think that you will be able to save your own lives after you have hunted down my people!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will you hunt down my people but save your own lives?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that the elders should not be inquiring of him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. It can also be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “Should I permit them to inquire of me at all?” or “They should not be inquiring of me at all.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Should I be inquired of at all by them?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel of something he already knows. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “a vine is not better than any tree with branches that is among the trees in a forest.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: how is a vine better than any tree with branches that is among the trees in a forest?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel of something he already knows. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “People do not take wood from a vine to make anything.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Do people take wood from a vine to make anything?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel of something he already knows. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “they do not make a peg from it to hang things on it.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: do they make a peg from it to hang anything on it?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel of something he already knows. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “If it is thrown into a fire as fuel … it is not good for anything.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: If it is thrown into a fire as fuel & is it good for anything?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that the woman is acting as if her prostitution was not bad enough and so she decided to sacrifice her children as well. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You must think that your acts of prostitution are a small matter.” or “I do not think your acts of prostitution are a small matter.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Are your acts of prostitution a small matter?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks the rhetorical question in order to rebuke Jerusalem. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Your heart must be very sick … that you would do all these things, deeds of a shameless prostitute!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: How sick is your heart & that you would do all these things, deeds of a shameless prostitute?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this as a leading question to emphasize the negative answer. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “It will not prosper.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will it prosper?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that the vine will certainly be judged. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. It can also be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “Someone will pull up its roots and pluck out its fruit so all of its growth of leaves will wither away.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Will it not be uprooted and stripped of its fruit so that it withers, and all its fresh growth will wither?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this as a leading question to emphasize the negative answer. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “It will not grow.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: will it grow?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that this will certainly happen. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “It will wither when the eastern wind touches it.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will it not wither when the eastern wind touches it?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this as a leading question in order to provide the answer. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “This is what these things mean.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Do you not know what these things mean?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this leading question to emphasize the negative answer. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “He will certainly not succeed.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will he succeed?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this leading question to emphasize the negative answer. This may be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: “The one doing these things will not escape.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will the one doing these things escape?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this leading question to emphasize the negative answer. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “If he breaks the covenant, he will certainly not escape.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: If he breaks the covenant, will he escape?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this leading question to emphasize the affirmative answer. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “it was my oath that the king of Jerusalem despised and my covenant that he broke.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: was it not my oath that he despised and my covenant that he broke?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel something he already knows. The question is a rebuke for the people who use the proverb. Alternate translation: “The people in the land of Israel have this proverb … ‘Fathers eat sour grapes, and the children’s teeth are made blunt’.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What do you mean, you who use this proverb & ‘Fathers eat sour grapes, and the children’s teeth are made blunt’?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this as a leading question in order to emphasize the negative answer. Alternate translation: “he will certainly not live!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: should that man live? Surely he will not!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question in order to emphasize the opposite. Alternate translation: “I do not greatly rejoice over the death of the wicked … but I do greatly rejoice if he turns away from his way so that he may live.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Do I greatly rejoice over the death of the wicked & and not in his turning away from his way so that he may live?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize the negative answer. Alternate translation: “then he will surely not live.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: then will he live?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize the negative answer. Alternate translation: “My ways are not unfair.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Are my ways unfair?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize the positive answer. Alternate translation: “It is your ways that are unfair.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is it not your ways that are unfair?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to comfort the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “There is no reason for you to die, house of Israel.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why should you die, house of Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this ask a leading question in order to introduce the answer. Alternate translation: “This is who your mother is.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who was your mother?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that the elders should not be inquiring of him. Alternate translation: “You should not come to inquire of me.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Have you come to inquire of me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this question in order to rebuke the people. Alternate translation: “This is not a high place where you are to bring offerings!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What is this high place where you bring offerings there?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this question to rebuke the people. Alternate translation: “You should not make yourselves unclean by doing the things that your fathers did.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why do you make yourselves unclean with the ways of your fathers?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this question to rebuke the people. Alternate translation: “You should not act like prostitutes, searching for disgusting things.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: So why do you act like prostitutes, searching for disgusting things?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this question to rebuke the people. Alternate translation: “I will not let you come close to me, house of Israel.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: So why should I let you seek me, house of Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people use this question to insult Ezekiel and dismiss what he is telling them. Alternate translation: “He is merely telling parables” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is he not a mere teller of parables?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question emphasizes that the people of Israel will not celebrate their king’s power, because it cannot resist the “sword.” Alternate translation: “The people of Judah will not celebrate about their king’s scepter.” or “we should not celebrate the power of our king’s scepter.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Should we rejoice in my son’s scepter?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question functions as a command. AT. “Son of man, go and judge. Go and judge the city of blood.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Now you, son of man, will you judge? Will you judge the city of blood?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this rhetorical question to emphasize how hurt they will be when he punishes them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Your heart will not stand and your hands will not be strong on the days when I myself will deal with you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will your heart stand, will your hands be strong on the days when I myself will deal with you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this rhetorical question as a command for Ezekiel. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. The cities of Jerusalem and Samaria are represented by Oholah and Oholibah. Alternate translation: “Son of man, you will judge Oholah and Oholibah!” or “Son of man, judge the people of those two cities represented by Oholah and Oholibah.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Son of man, will you judge Oholah and Oholibah?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question expects a positive answer and emphasizes the results of Tyre’s destruction. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “The islands will quake … in your midst.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will not the islands quake & in your midst?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question expects a negative answer and emphasizes Tyre being different from all other cities. It can be expressed as a statement. Alternate translation: “No other city is like Tyre, who has now been brought to silence in the middle of the sea.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who is like Tyre, who has now been brought to silence in the middle of the sea?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question expects a negative answer to emphasize the irony when one who claims to be a god is destroyed by men. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You will not say ‘I am a god’ to the face of one who kills you!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: Will you truly say, “I am a god” to the face of one who kills you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Who is as great as you are?” Yahweh uses this question to introduce a new topic. Pharaoh thought that his nation was the greatest, but God is about to talk about another great nation. Alternate translation: “You think that there is no country whose power is as great as the power of your country.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: In your greatness, who are you like?

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Which of these trees in Eden had as much glory as you and was as great as you?” God asks Pharaoh this question to show him that the parable applies to him and his country. It can start with “So Pharaoh” or “So Egypt.” Alternate translation: “None of the trees in Eden was your equal in glory and greatness!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Which of the trees in Eden was your equal in glory and greatness?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question really makes a statement. Alternate translation: “You are not more beautiful than anyone else.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Are you really more beautiful than anyone else?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people ask this question to emphasize that they have no hope of living. Alternate translation: “We have no hope of living.” or “We will certainly die.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: How can we live?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he does not want the people of Israel to die. Alternate translation: “Do not choose to die, house of Israel!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: For why should you die, house of Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh used this question to rebuke the people. Alternate translation: “You should not possess this land!” or “You do not deserve this land!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Should you really possess the land?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this question to scold the leaders for not taking care of the people. Alternate translation: “Shepherds should feed the flock and take care of it.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Should not shepherds guard the flock?

contextId.occurrenceNote: God uses these questions to scold Israel’s leaders, who are spoken of as if they were the stronger animals in the flock that were unkind to the weaker ones. You can translate this as a statement as in the UST. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Is it not enough & feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people use a question to express their surprise at what they saw. Alternate translation: “I cannot believe these are really the people of Yahweh!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Are these really the people of Yahweh?

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two questions are used to accuse Gog of attacking Israel without cause. These can be translated as statements. Alternate translation: “It is not right for you to assemble your army to plunder, to carry off silver and gold, to take their livestock and property, and to haul away much plunder!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Have you come to plunder? Have you assembled your armies & to haul away much plunder?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that Gog will indeed hear about the people living in Israel. Alternate translation: “On that day, when my people Israel are living securely, you will hear about them.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: On that day & learn about them?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he was the one who brought Gog to the land of Israel. Alternate translation: “You are the one … bring you against them.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Are you not the one & bring you against them?

contextId.occurrenceNote: “that were shiny like bronze that has been polished.” This describes the feet of the creatures. Alternate translation: “and they shone like polished bronze” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: that shone like polished bronze

contextId.occurrenceNote: Lightning flashes and then disappears quickly, and the creatures moved from one place to another quickly. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **appearance**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “The living creatures were moving swiftly back and forth, and they looked like lightning” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: The living creatures were moving swiftly back and forth, and they had the appearance of lightning

contextId.occurrenceNote: These sentences are not complete because Ezekiel was showing that he was excited about what he saw. They can be translated as complete sentences: “The wings sounded like … water. They sounded like … moved. They sounded like … rainstorm. They sounded like … army.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Like & waters & ike & moved & ike & rainstorm & ike & army.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are: (1) “Like the sound of very big storm” or (2) “Like the sound of a very large crowd of people” Alternate translation: “There was a sound that was loud like a big storm” or “There was a sound that was loud like a very large crowd of people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Like the sound of a rainstorm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Water cannot stand up, and the people’s knees will be so weak that the people are unable to stand on their legs. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: knee & weak as water

contextId.occurrenceNote: Like jackals that scavenge for food and shelter among the abandoned ruins of cities, the prophets are using the destruction of Jerusalem for their own benefit. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like jackals in the wastelands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh compares growing quickly with the way a plant grows quickly. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: I made you grow like a plant in a field

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people being unfaithful to him as if they were acting like women who sleep with men to whom they are not married. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: why do you act like prostitutes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that the sword will be so shiny that light reflects off of it easily and brightly. Alternate translation: “so that it flashes like lightning” or “so that light reflects off of it as brightly as lightning” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: in order to be like lightning

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares how the sword is well polished and how it reflects light to appear like lightning. Alternate translation: “My sword is polished and flashes like lightning” or “It is polished and reflects light as being like lightning” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: It is made like lightning

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that the sword is so shiny that light reflects off of it easily and brightly. Alternate translation: “and light reflects off of it as brightly as lightning” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: so it will be like lightning

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the prophets of Israel to lions who attack and kill their victims. Alternate translation: “They kill people for they are like roaring lions who attack and kill their prey. They take peoples’ precious wealth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a roaring lion tearing apart a victim & hey consume life and take precious wealth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares Israel’s princes to wolves who attack and kill their victims. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Her princes within her are like wolves tearing apart their victims

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the size of the mens’ private parts to those of a donkey to show how wicked Oholibah’s desires were. This is an exaggeration as they could not be as large as those of a donkey. Alternate translation: “whose private parts were very long, like those of a donkey” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: whose private parts were like those of donkeys

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the volume of the mens’ emissions to those of a horse to show how wicked Oholibah’s desires were. This is an exaggeration as they could not be like those of a horse. Alternate translation: “whose reproductive emissions were huge, like those of a horse” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: whose reproductive emissions were like those of horses

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of how he will cause Tyre to be completely destroyed. Alternate translation: “I will cause the armies to completely destroy the city, and they will leave nothing there” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: I will sweep her dust away and make her like a bare rock

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh uses a simile to describe how Nebuchadnezzar’s army will enter into the city of Tyre. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: When he enters your gates, he will enter as men come into a city whose walls have been broken down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Tyre is compared to other cities that no longer had people living in them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: When I make you a desolate city, like the other cities that are not inhabited

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sails of the ship are compared to the banners or flags of Tyre. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Your sails were made from colorful linen from Egypt that served as your banner

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the ruler of Tyre compares himself to Daniel the prophet in how wise he thought he was. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: you think that you are wiser than Daniel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Egypt was stronger than other nations, like lions are stronger than other animals. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a young lion among the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Pharaoh was powerful, but he only caused trouble for others, like this monster in the water. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a monster in the seas

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares how the people behaved to a woman’s unclean menstruation rags. This emphasizes how disgusting their behaviors were to Yahweh. Alternate translation: “Their ways were as disgusting to me as the unclean menstruation of a woman” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Their ways were like the unclean menstruation of a woman before me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means Gog will bring destruction like a large storm does. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: you will go up as a storm goes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means the army will be so large that it will cover the entire land. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: a cloud covering the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eye is a synecdoche for the person whose eye it is. Alternate translation: “I will not pity you” (See: and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my eye will not have pity on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the Israelites as if they were a woman who sleeps with many people. Alternate translation: “I was sad because they were like a wife who has left me to sleep with other men” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I was grieved by their promiscuous heart that turned away from me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the Israelites as if they were a married woman who looks at other men and desires to sleep with them. Alternate translation: “by the way they desired strongly to worship idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: by their eyes that whored after their idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eye is a synecdoche for the person whose eye it is. Alternate translation: “For I will not pity you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: For my eyes will not pity you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eye is a synecdoche for the person whose eye it is. Alternate translation: “I will not look on them with compassion” or “I will not be compassionate to them” (See: and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: For my eye will not look compassionately

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hands and knees are synecdoches for the people themselves. Alternate translation: “Everyone will be so terrified that they will be unable to work and their knees will become weak so that they cannot stand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Every hand will falter and every knee will be weak as water

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hands” is a synecdoche for the people. Alternate translation: “the people of the land will be so afraid that their hands will tremble” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the hands of the people of the land will tremble in fear

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eye is a synecdoche for the person whose eye it is. Alternate translation: “I will not look on them with compassion” or “I will not be compassionate to them” (See: and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my eye will not have compassion

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eye is a synecdoche for the person whose eye it is. Alternate translation: “Do not have compassion” (See: and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not let your eyes have compassion

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eye is a synecdoche for the person whose eye it is. Alternate translation: “I will not look on them with compassion” or “I will not be compassionate to them” (See: and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my eye will not look with compassion

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” represents the person and his emotions. Alternate translation: “discourage the righteous person” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: discourage the heart of the righteous person

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “faces” represents the people. Alternate translation: “Turn back” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Turn back your faces

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “navel” refers to the umbilical cord that is attached to the navel. Alternate translation: “you mother did not cut your umbilical cord” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: your mother did not cut your navel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “eye” represents the person who sees. Alternate translation: “Nobody who saw you had compassion for you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: No eye had compassion for you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “life” represents the person. Alternate translation: “I will hand you over” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I will hand your life over

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hands” represents the people who work with their hands. The words “poor” and “needy” emphasize that these are people who cannot help themselves. Alternate translation: “She did not help the people who could not help themselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: She did not strengthen the hands of the poor and needy people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “mouth” represents the person who speaks. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “You did not even mention your sister Sodom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Sodom your sister was not even mentioned by your mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “strong arm” represents a strong person. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “There will be no need for a strong person or many people to pull it out” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: No strong arm or many people will be needed to pull it out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “soul” represents the person. Alternate translation: “The person who sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: The soul who sins

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “eye” represents Yahweh. Alternate translation: “I spared them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my eye spared them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” represents Yahweh and turning his hand away means that he does not do what he was going to do. Alternate translation: “But I did not do that” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I turned my hand away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “eyes” represents the person who looks to the idols to worship them. Alternate translation: “They were longing after their fathers’ idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Their eyes were longing after their fathers’ idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “face” represents the person. By mentioning the opposite directions, Yahweh refers to everyone who lives in the north, in the south, and everywhere in between. Alternate translation: “every person who lives in that area” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: every face from the south to the north

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the Israelites are referred to by their “eyes” to emphasize what they see. Alternate translation: “before them” or “before the Israelite people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: before their eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of people becoming afraid, as if their hearts were fainting. Also, this speaks of the people fainting as a result of fear. Alternate translation: “for everyone will become fearful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for every heart will faint away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the whole person is referred to by his “heart” to emphasize his emotions and will. Here the idea of “standing” is an idiom that means to be courageous. Alternate translation: “Will you stand” or “Will you be courageous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Will your heart stand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the whole person is referred to by his “hands.” Alternate translation: “will you be strong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: will your hands be strong

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the house in general. The reference to the “middle” emphasizes that what was done happened openly in the temple and defiled the whole place. Alternate translation: “in my own house” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: in the middle of my house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “food” refers specifically to meat. Alternate translation: “Place pieces of meat” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Gather pieces of food

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Ezekiel’s wife. Yahweh refers to Ezekiel by the part of his body he uses to see his wife. Alternate translation: “your wife, whom you love very much, from” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the desire of your eyes from

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh refers to the people by their “eyes.” Alternate translation: “the building that you delight to look at” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the delight of your eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh refers to the people by their “soul” to emphasize their inner feelings. Alternate translation: “the building that you truly love” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the yearning of your soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the face represents being in the presence of another person. Alternate translation: “in the presence of” or “before” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: to the face of

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “heart” represents the whole person, emphasizing the person’s thoughts. Alternate translation: “You were arrogant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Your heart was arrogant

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “man’s foot” represents people. Alternate translation: “No man will walk through the land of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: No man’s foot will pass through it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “animal’s foot” represents animals. Alternate translation: “not even a wild animal will walk through it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: no wild animal’s foot will pass through it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The foot here is a synecdoche for the whole person. Alternate translation: “people will no longer stir the waters up with their feet” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the foot of man will no longer stir the waters up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mountains” represents the whole land of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: against the mountains of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, “lips” and “tongues” represent people speaking. Alternate translation: “people are saying bad things about you, and the nations are telling bad stories about you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: you have been the subject of slanderous lips and tongues, and of people’s stories

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” refers to the mountain of Israel which here represents the trees on the mountain that will grow fruit. Alternate translation: “your trees will grow branches and bear fruit” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: you will grow branches and bear fruit

contextId.occurrenceNote: The tribe of Judah lived in the southern kingdom of Israel which was called Judah. Here the name is used to refer to the whole southern kingdom. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Joseph was Ephraim’s father. The tribe of Ephraim lived in the northern kingdom of Israel. Here the names are used to represent the whole northern kingdom. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: For Joseph, the branch of Ephraim

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people are represented by their “eyes” to emphasize what they see. Alternate translation: “while they watched you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: before their eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gog will not do these things alone. His army will do most of them. Alternate translation: “My army and I will” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I will

contextId.occurrenceNote: “when the God of Israel had come to destroy the city.” If the earlier Hebrew reading “when I had come to destroy the city” is used, then “destroy the city” is a synecdoche for “prophesy that the city will be destroyed.” Alternate translation: “when I had come to prophesy that the city will be destroyed” or “when I had come to prophesy that the God of Israel will destroy the city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: when he had come to destroy the city

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of himself by name to remind Ezekiel and the people that what he is saying is important. Alternate translation: “I, the Lord Yahweh, say this” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: The Lord Yahweh says this

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of himself by name to remind Ezekiel and the people that what he is saying is important. Alternate translation: “I, the Lord Yahweh, say this” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: the Lord Yahweh says this

contextId.occurrenceNote: Since these were God’s words to Pharaoh, it can also be translated with the first person. Alternate translation: “The cedar trees in my garden were not as great as that tree” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: Cedars in the garden of God could not equal it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Since Yahweh is speaking this can be stated in first person. Alternate translation: “Therefore, this is what I, Yahweh the Lord, say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: Therefore the Lord Yahweh says this

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “your” refers to the people of Israel. This can be stated in third person. Alternate translation: “but it is their ways” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: but it is your ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in the first person. Alternate translation: “I, the Lord Yahweh, say this” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: The Lord Yahweh says this

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in first person. Alternate translation: “For this is what I, the Lord Yahweh, say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: For the Lord Yahweh says this

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in first person. Alternate translation: “this is what I, the Lord Yahweh, say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: the Lord Yahweh says this

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in first person. Alternate translation: “This is what I, the Lord Yahweh, say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: The Lord Yahweh says this

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, **likeness** means that what Ezekiel saw looked like these things. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **likeness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “what looked like four living creatures” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: the likeness of four living creatures

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **appearance**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “This is what they looked like” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: This was their appearance

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **appearance**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “The four creatures looked like people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: They had the likeness of a man

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ezekiel is describing the faces of the creatures on their front side. Here, **likeness** means that what Ezekiel saw looked like a man’s face. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **likeness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “The face of each creature looked like the face of a man” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: The likeness of their faces was like the face of a man

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, **likeness** means that what Ezekiel saw looked like these things. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the words **likeness** and **appearance**, you can express the same ideas with verbal forms. Alternate translation: “As for what the living creatures looked like, they were similar to burning coals” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: As for the likeness of the living creatures, their appearance was like burning coals

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, **likeness** refers to what the four wheels looked like. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **likeness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “all four of the wheels looked the same” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: the four had the same likeness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The abstract nouns “appearance” and “structure” can be translated as verbs. Alternate translation: “they appeared to be made with one wheel going through another wheel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: their appearance and structure was like a wheel intersecting another wheel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, **likeness** means that what Ezekiel saw looked like “an expansive dome.” If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **likeness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “what looked like an expansive dome” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: the likeness of an expansive dome

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, **likeness** means that what Ezekiel saw looked like a throne. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **likeness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “was something that looked like a throne” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: was the likeness of a throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **likeness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “on what looked like a throne there was” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: on the likeness of the throne was

contextId.occurrenceNote: The person’s body above the hips looked like glowing metal that had fire in it. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **appearance**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “from what appeared to be his hips up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: from the appearance of his hips up

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **appearance**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “all around him below what appeared to be his hips, I saw what looked like fire and a bright light” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: from the appearance of his hips downward the appearance of fire and brightness all around

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **appearance**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “The brightness surrounding it appeared to be like the way a rainbow appears in the clouds on a rainy day” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Like the appearance of a rainbow in the clouds on a rainy day was the appearance of the bright light surrounding it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, **likeness** means that what Ezekiel saw looked like the glory of Yahweh. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the ideas behind the words **appearance** and **likeness**, you can express the same idea with verbal forms. Alternate translation: “It appeared to be what looked like the glory of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: It was the appearance of the likeness of the glory of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be restated to remove the abstract nouns “lamentations,” “mourning,” and “woe.” Alternate translation: “someone had written on it that these people would lament, be sad the way they would be if someone they loved had died, and have bad things happen to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: written on it were lamentations, mourning, and woe

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, **likeness** means that what Ezekiel saw looked like a man. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the ideas behind the words **likeness** and **appearance**, you can express the same ideas with verbal forms. Alternate translation: “there was someone who appeared to be a man” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: a likeness with the appearance of a man

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **appearance**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “what appeared to be his hips … what appeared to be something shining” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: the appearance of his hips & the appearance of something shining

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wrath is spoken of as if it were a liquid that Yahweh could pour out of a container. The word “Jerusalem” is a metonym for the people in the city. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **outpouring**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “when you pour out your wrath on Jerusalem” or “when you punish the people of Jerusalem because you are very angry with them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: in the outpouring of your wrath on Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **appearance**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be put into active form. Alternate translation: “I will fill the streams with your blood” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be put into active form. Alternate translation: “When I make the land of Egypt a place where no one is living” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: When I make the land of Egypt an abandoned place

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” is a metonym for a soldier who kills people with a sword.This can be put into active form.
