contextId.quoteString: who were killed by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be put in active form. Alternate translation: “I have given Egypt to the sword” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: She has been given to the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be put in active form. Alternate translation: “all those whom enemies killed in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: all of those who were killed, who fell by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be put in active form. Alternate translation: “Her enemies killed them all” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: all of them were killed

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Broken” here represents “destroyed.” This can be put in active form. Alternate translation: “I will destroy you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you & will be broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be put in active form. Alternate translation: “Others will lay him in the midst of the uncircumcised” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: he will be laid down in the midst of the uncircumcised

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “and he does not warn the people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: with the result that the people are not warned

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “the city” refers to “Jerusalem.” If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The Babylonians have destroyed Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The city has been captured

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has given us the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The land has been given to us

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “no one will live in the mountains of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the mountains of Israel will be deserted

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that someone plays very well on a stringed instrument” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: that is well played on a stringed instrument

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Then they scattered because they did not have a shepherd” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Then they were scattered without a shepherd

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in the active form. Alternate translation: “because all the beasts in the fields steal my flock and eat them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: because my flock has become plunder and food for all the beasts in the fields

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will not allow anyone to plunder them” or “I will not allow anyone to steal them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they will no longer be plunder

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. This may be an exaggeration for emphasis. Alternate translation: “People will not live in your cities” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: Your cities will not be inhabited

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “They are in ruins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: They have been destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the cities that people have left behind” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the forsaken cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “my people, Israel, will plow your ground and sow it with seed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: you will be plowed and sown with seed

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Then people will live in the cities and will rebuild the ruins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The cities will be inhabited and the ruins rebuilt

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “people to live on you mountains as they did before” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: you to be inhabited as you previously were

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I dispersed them through the lands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they were dispersed through the lands

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “For Yahweh has forced them out of his land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: For they have been thrown out of his land

contextId.occurrenceNote: “know this” or “you can be sure of this.” Yahweh says this to emphasize that it is not because the people are good that he will restore them. This phrase can be moved to the beginning of the verse. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: let this be known to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. This could mean: (1) Alternate translation: “that enemies had torn down” or (2) Alternate translation: “that people could not get into” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: that were torn down

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the people have now rebuilt them and have started living there again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: are now fortified and inhabited

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “is set apart” can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “Like the great number of sheep that the people set apart for sacrifices or bring to Jerusalem for the appointed feasts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Like the flock is set apart for sacrifices, like the flock in Jerusalem at her appointed feasts

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “as Yahweh had commanded me to speak” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: as I was commanded

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “these people that enemies and disasters have killed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: these who have been killed

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “as Yahweh had commanded me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: as I was commanded

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will call you to come for war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: You will be called

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that I have gathered together” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: that has been gathered

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will bring the Israelites out” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the land’s people will be brought out

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will make mountains fall down” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The mountains will be thrown down

contextId.occurrenceNote: That can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “they all became fat while grazing in Bashan” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they were all fattened in Bashan

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “the Babylonians captured the city of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the city was captured

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “they killed the burnt offering” or “they killed the animals that they would burn as an offering” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the burnt offering was slaughtered

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “they would put the flesh of the offerings on the tables” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the flesh of the offerings would be put on the tables

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “no one will open it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: it will not be opened

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “that they need to do in it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: that is done in it

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “or any creature that a bird or a wild animal has torn apart” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: or animal torn by a beast, whether bird or beast

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “that you gave for the holy place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: reserved for the holy place

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “you will use for” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: will be used for

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the Levites will open the gate facing east for him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the gate facing east will be opened for him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “a river that no one could cross on foot” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: a river that could not be crossed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “The leaders of the Israelites will assign land to the priests” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The priests will have land assigned to them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “we” refers to Ezekiel and the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])
contextId.quoteString: Should we

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “our” refers to Ezekiel and the Israelites who have been in Babylon since the time the Babylonians forced King Jehoiachin to leave Jerusalem, but not to the reader. Alternate translation: “after we became captives” or “after the Babylonians took us as captives to Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: of our captivity

contextId.occurrenceNote: “empty visions for you Ammonites … with lies for you Ammonites.” The word “you” refers to the people of Ammon. In the original Biblical language, the word “your” is feminine singular and refers to the nation of Ammon. Nations were often thought of as a woman. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-gendernotations]])
contextId.quoteString: empty visions for you & with lies for you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “her” refers to Jerusalem. Cities were often thought of as a woman. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-gendernotations]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “her” refers to Jerusalem. Cities were often thought of as a woman. This continues through verse 32. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-gendernotations]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: her & herself

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a hypothetical situation that could have happened but did not. Yahweh did not send Ezekiel to people who did not understand his language. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: if I sent you to them, they would have listened to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to righteous and wicked people. Alternate translation: “those who are righteous … those who are wicked” or “the righteous people … the wicked people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the righteous & the wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to people with low status and people who are exalted. Alternate translation: “those who are lowly … those who are exalted” or “those with low status … those with high status” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the lowly & the exalted

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to wicked people. Alternate translation: “those who are wicked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to unclean and clean things. Something that God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if it were physically unclean. Alternate translation: “things that are unclean and things that are clean” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the unclean and the clean

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to poor and needy people. Alternate translation: “those who are poor and needy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the poor and needy

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to his dead wife. Alternate translation: “your dead wife” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the dead

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the deeps” means the deep waters of the sea. Alternate translation: “the deep waters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the deeps

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here purple cloth or yarn is referred to by just its color. Alternate translation: “purple cloth” or “purple yarn” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: purple

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the slain” means the people of Sidon whom their enemies would kill. Alternate translation: “the slain people will fall” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the slain will fall

contextId.occurrenceNote: The nominal adjective “the wicked” can be stated as “the wicked person.” Alternate translation: “to the wicked person” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: to the wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ezekiel speaks of himself as if he were another person. Alternate translation: “to me, Ezekiel … upon me there” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: to Ezekiel & upon him there

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “your” and “you” are second person plural and refer to the people of Israel in general. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: your burnt offerings & your peace offerings & accept you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “you” refers to the people of Israel and so is plural. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The abstract nouns “wisdom” and “skill” can be translated using the adjectives “wise” and “skillful.” Alternate translation: “You have become wealthy by your own wisdom and skill” or “You have become wealthy by being wise and skillful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: You have made yourself wealthy with wisdom and skill

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “myself” adds emphasis. God would do this because the shepherds were not doing it. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: I myself

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “myself” emphasizes that it is Yahweh who will judge. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: I myself

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “you” is plural and refers to the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: What do you mean, you who use this proverb

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “you” switches to singular and refers to only one sister, but the situation is probably the same for both sisters. If one sister must be specified in your language, refer to Oholibah here. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: you bathed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “you” switches to singular and refers to only one sister, but the situation is probably the same for both sisters. If one sister must be specified in your language, refer to Oholibah here. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: you sat

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “you” refers to the nation of Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: a sword against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” is plural. God is speaking to the people of Mount Seir, rather than to a single mountain. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: but you will know

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “you” is singular. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: You will

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “you” is singular and refers to whoever is the prince in Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: you will take

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “you” is plural and refers to the prince and the rest of the people of the house of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: for you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is plural and refers to the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is plural and refers to the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: you

dublin_core.creator: Door43 World Missions Community
dublin_core.description: Open-licensed exegetical notes that provide historical, cultural, and linguistic information for translators. It provides translators and checkers with pertinent, just-in-time information to help them make the best possible translation decisions.
dublin_core.subject: TSV Translation Notes
dublin_core.title: unfoldingWord® Translation Notes

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Burn a third of your hair” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-fraction]])
contextId.quoteString: Burn a third of it

contextId.occurrenceNote: “take one of the three piles of hair” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-fraction]])
contextId.quoteString: take a third of the hair

contextId.occurrenceNote: “let the wind blow the last third of your hair in different directions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-fraction]])
contextId.quoteString: scatter a third of it to the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: “three hundred and ninety days” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: 390 days

contextId.occurrenceNote: “three hundred and ninety days” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: 390 days

contextId.occurrenceNote: “20 shekels per day.” A shekel is a unit of weight equal to about 11 grams. Alternate translation: 200 grams of bread each day” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bweight]])
contextId.quoteString: twenty shekels per day

contextId.occurrenceNote: “25 men” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: twenty-five men

contextId.occurrenceNote: “7 months.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: seven months

contextId.occurrenceNote: “and there were 30 rooms all around the pavement” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: with thirty rooms next to the pavement

contextId.occurrenceNote: “four thousand five hunded cubits.” This is about 2.4 kilometers. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: 4,500 cubits

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the thirtieth year of Ezekiel’s life. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: In the thirtieth year

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to make explicit the time period of which this is the sixth year. Alternate translation: “in the sixth year of the exile of King Jehoiachin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in the sixth year

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implicit information may be supplied. Alternate translation: “in the seventh year of the exile of King Jehoiachin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in the seventh year

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means multiple times. Alternate translation: “again and again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: even a third time

contextId.occurrenceNote: “in year 9.” This refers to how long they had been in exile under King Jehoiachin. Alternate translation: “in the ninth year of the exile of King Jehoiachin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in the ninth year

contextId.occurrenceNote: “in year 11.” This means the eleventh year after King Jehoiachin was taken into exile in Babylon. Alternate translation: “in the eleventh year of the exile of King Jehoiachin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in the eleventh year

contextId.occurrenceNote: “on day 1 of the month.” It is uncertain which month of the Hebrew calendar Ezekiel meant. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: on the first day of the month

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated clearly that this was the tenth year of Jehoiachin’s exile. Alternate translation: “In the tenth year of the exile of King Jehoiachin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: In the tenth year

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was after King Jehoiachin and the people of Judah were taken as exiles to Babylon. Alternate translation: “in the twenty-seventh year of the exile of King Jehoiachin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in the twenty-seventh year

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the twelfth year of the reign of King Jehoiachin. Alternate translation: “of the twelfth year of the exile of King Jehoiachin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: of the twelfth year

contextId.occurrenceNote: “year 12 … day 5 … month 10” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the twelfth year & fifth day & tenth month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This “seventh” is the ordinal number for seven. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: seventh month
